en: From the corner of the divan of Persian saddle-bags on which he was lying, smoking, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could just catch the gleam of the honey-sweet and honey-coloured blossoms of a laburnum, whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden of a beauty so flamelike as theirs; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in flight flitted across the long tussore-silk curtains that were stretched in front of the huge window, producing a kind of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pallid, jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ.
vi: Từ góc chiếc đi-văng bọc thảm giả túi yên lạc đà Ba Tư mà trên đó y nằm hút, theo thói quen, vô số điếu thuốc, huân tước Henry Wotton chỉ có thể loáng thoáng thấy được những bông hoa ngọt-mật và màu-mật của một cây kim tước mà những cái cành run rẩy của nó dường như khó khăn lắm mới có thể mang nổi gánh nặng một vẻ đẹp rừng rực nhường ấy; và thỉnh thoảng, những chiếc bóng dị thường của lũ chim đang bay lượn lại vụt qua các tấm màn lụa tuýt-so dài căng trước ô cửa rộng, gây nên cảm giác gì đó từa tựa như một ấn tượng Nhật Bản nhất thời, và khiến y nghĩ về những họa sỹ mặt xanh nanh vàng ở Tokyo, những kẻ, nhờ vào sự trung gian của một nghệ thuật vốn dĩ tất yếu là bất động, đã cố gắng chuyển tải ý thức về sự mau lẹ và sự chuyển động. Tiếng rì rầm rầu rĩ của lũ ong đang len lỏi qua bãi cỏ dài chưa cắt, hoặc xoay tròn với sự cố chấp đơn điệu quanh các cái sừng thiếp vàng phủ bụi phấn của cây kim ngân bò lan um tùm, dường như khiến cho cảnh tĩnh mịch ấy lại còn ngột ngạt hơn. Tiếng gầm âm ỉ của thành London hệt như nốt buộc-đông của cây đàn ống xa xôi.
tr: İran heybeleriyle döşenmiş divanın köşesinde uzanmış, huyu olduğu üzere sayısız sigara tüttüren Lord Henry Wotton, bulunduğu yerden sarı salkım ağacının balrengi, bal tatlısı çiçeklerini seçebiliyordu. Ağacın titrek dalları, böylesi aleve benzer bir güzelliğin yükünü taşımakta güçlük çeker gibiydi. Kocaman pencerenin önünde gerili duran uzun, ipekli perdelerin üzerine arada düş gibi kuş gölgeleri vuruyordu. İlk bakışta bir Japon havası çağrıştıran bu perdeler Lord Henry’ye, Tokyo’nun solgun, zümrüt benizli ressamlarını anımsatıyordu; zorunluluk gereği durağan olan bir sanat aracılığıyla hareket ve hız aktarmaya çalışan ressamlar. Yüksek, biçilmemiş otlar arasında kendilerine yol açmaya çalışan ya da sere serpe frenkasmalarının tozlu, yaldızlı boynuzlarının çevresinde tekdüze bir ısrarla dönüp duran arıların donuk mırıltısı, ortalığın dinginliğini büsbütün sıkıcı kılar gibiydi. Londra’nın hafif uğultusu uzaktaki bir org melodisinin pes sedasını andırıyordu.
es: Lord Henry Wotton, que había consumido ya, según su costumbre, innumerables cigarrillos, vislumbraba, desde el extremo del sofá donde estaba tumbado —tapizado al estilo de las alfombras persas—, el resplandor de las floraciones de un codeso, de dulzura y color de miel, cuyas ramas estremecidas apenas parecían capaces de soportar el peso de una belleza tan deslumbrante como la suya; y, de cuando en cuando, las sombras fantásticas de pájaros en vuelo se deslizaban sobre las largas cortinas de seda india colgadas delante de las inmensas ventanas, produciendo algo así como un efecto japonés, lo que le hacía pensar en los pintores de Tokyo, de rostros tan pálidos como el jade, que, por medio de un arte necesariamente inmóvil, tratan de transmitir la sensación de velocidad y de movimiento. El zumbido obstinado de las abejas, abriéndose camino entre el alto césped sin segar, o dando vueltas con monótona insistencia en torno a los polvorientos cuernos dorados de las desordenadas madreselvas, parecían hacer más opresiva la quietud, mientras los ruidos confusos de Londres eran como las notas graves de un órgano lejano.
vi_translation: From the corner of the Persian camel saddlebag-patterned divan on which he habitually lay smoking countless cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could only faintly see the honey-sweet and honey-colored blossoms of a laburnum tree whose trembling branches seemed to struggle under the weight of such a blazing beauty; and occasionally, the strange shadows of birds in flight would flicker across the long tussore silk curtains drawn before the wide window, evoking a sensation somewhat akin to a fleeting Japanese impression, and making him think of the green-faced, yellow-fanged artists in Tokyo, who, through the medium of an inherently static art, had attempted to convey a sense of swiftness and movement. The mournful hum of bees threading through the long, uncut grass, or circling with monotonous persistence around the golden-tipped horns of the overgrown honeysuckle, seemed to make the stillness even more oppressive. The distant roar of London was like the pedal note of a far-off organ.
tr_translation: Lord Henry Wotton, who was lying in the corner of the divan adorned with Iranian saddlebags, smoking countless cigarettes as was his habit, could make out the honey-colored, honey-sweet flowers of the yellow wisteria tree from where he was. The tree's trembling branches seemed to struggle under the burden of such flame-like beauty. Occasionally, the shadows of birds, like dreams, would fall upon the long, silken curtains stretched in front of the large window. At first glance, these curtains, which evoked a Japanese atmosphere, reminded Lord Henry of the pale, emerald-faced painters of Tokyo; painters who tried to convey movement and speed through the necessarily static medium of art. The dull hum of bees, either trying to make their way through the tall, uncut grass or circling monotonously around the dusty, gilded horns of the sprawling French marigolds, seemed to make the tranquility of the surroundings all the more tedious. The faint hum of London resembled the bass notes of a distant organ melody.
es_translation: Lord Henry Wotton, who had already consumed, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, glimpsed, from the end of the sofa where he was lying —upholstered in the style of Persian carpets—, the glow of the blossoms of a broom, sweet and honey-colored, whose trembling branches barely seemed capable of bearing the weight of such dazzling beauty as theirs; and, from time to time, the fantastic shadows of birds in flight slid over the long Indian silk curtains hanging in front of the immense windows, producing something like a Japanese effect, which made him think of the painters of Tokyo, with faces as pale as jade, who, through a necessarily motionless art, try to convey the sensation of speed and movement. The obstinate buzzing of bees, making their way through the tall unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence around the dusty golden horns of the disordered honeysuckles, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive, while the confused noises of London were like the deep notes of a distant organ.

en: In the centre of the room, clamped to an upright easel, stood the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary personal beauty, and in front of it, some little distance away, was sitting the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance some years ago caused, at the time, such public excitement and gave rise to so many strange conjectures.
vi: Ở giữa phòng, kẹp chặt vào một giá vẽ đứng thẳng, đặt bức chân dung toàn thân của một thanh niên có vẻ đẹp cá nhân khác thường, và ngồi trước mặt nó, hơi xa hơn đôi chút, là chính nghệ sỹ sáng tác, Basil Hallward, người mà sự biến mất đột ngột vài năm trước của y đã gây nên, vào thời ấy, sự náo động quá đỗi trong công chúng, và tạo ra cơ man phỏng đoán lạ lùng.
tr: Odanın en ortasında, ayaklı bir kanvasta, olağanüstü güzellikteki bir genç erkeğin boy resmi duruyordu. Önünde, biraz ötede de portrenin ressamı oturmaktaydı: birkaç yıl önce, ansızın ortadan yitmesiyle bir süre büyük heyecan yaratan ve bir sürü garip tahminlere yol açan Basil Hallward.
es: En el centro de la pieza, sobre un caballete recto, descansaba el retrato de cuerpo entero de un joven de extraordinaria belleza; y, delante, a cierta distancia, estaba sentado el artista en persona, el Basil Hallward cuya repentina desaparición, hace algunos años, tanto conmoviera a la sociedad y diera origen a tan extrañas suposiciones.
vi_translation: In the middle of the room, clamped tightly onto an upright easel, was a full-length portrait of a young man with extraordinary personal beauty, and sitting in front of it, a little further away, was the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance a few years ago had caused, at that time, an overwhelming public sensation and generated a myriad of strange speculations.
tr_translation: In the very center of the room, on a standing canvas, stood a portrait of an extraordinarily beautiful young man. In front of it, a little further away, sat the painter of the portrait: Basil Hallward, who had caused quite a stir a few years ago by suddenly disappearing and giving rise to a host of strange speculations.
es_translation: In the center of the room, on a straight easel, rested the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary beauty; and, in front, at a certain distance, sat the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance a few years ago so moved society and gave rise to such strange suppositions.

en: Lord Henry stretched himself out on the divan and laughed.
vi: Huân tước Henry duỗi người trên đi-văng và bật cười.
tr: Lord Henry divana boylu boyunca uzanarak güldü.
es: Lord Henry, estirándose sobre el sofá, dejó escapar una carcajada.
vi_translation: Lord Henry stretched out on the couch and laughed.
tr_translation: Lord Henry lay full length on the divan and laughed.
es_translation: Lord Henry, stretching out on the sofa, let out a laugh.

en: “Being natural is simply a pose, and the most irritating pose I know,” cried Lord Henry, laughing; and the two young men went out into the garden together and ensconced themselves on a long bamboo seat that stood in the shade of a tall laurel bush. The sunlight slipped over the polished leaves. In the grass, white daisies were tremulous.
vi: “Sống thuận tự nhiên cũng chỉ để làm màu thôi, và là kiểu làm màu khó chịu nhất mà tôi từng biết,” huân tước Henry la lớn, bật cười; và hai người đàn ông trẻ trung ấy cùng đi vào vườn, rồi yên vị trên chiếc ghế tre dài đặt dưới bóng mát bụi nguyệt quế cao. Ánh nắng trượt qua những chiếc lá bóng loáng. Trên cỏ, bạch cúc rung rinh.
tr: Lord Henry, “Doğal olmak da yapmacıklıktan başka bir şey değildir, hem de yapmacıklıkların en sinir bozucusu, bence,” diyerek güldü. İki genç erkek birlikte bahçeye çıktılar, yüksek bir taflanın gölgesindeki uzun bambu sıraya oturdular. Güneş, cilalı yapraklardan aşağı kayıyordu. Otların arasındaki beyaz papatyalar titreşimler içindeydi.
es: —La naturalidad también es afectación, y la más irritante que conozco —exclamó lord Henry, echándose a reír. Los dos jóvenes salieron juntos al jardín, acomodándose en un amplio banco de bambú colocado a la sombra de un laurel. La luz del sol resbalaba sobre las hojas enceradas. Sobre la hierba temblaban margaritas blancas.
vi_translation: “Living in harmony with nature is just for show, and it's the most annoying kind of showmanship I've ever known,” Lord Henry shouted, laughing; and the two young men walked into the garden, then settled on a long bamboo bench placed in the shade of a tall laurel bush. Sunlight glided through the glossy leaves. On the grass, daisies swayed.
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed and said, "Being natural is just another pose, and the most irritating one at that, in my opinion." Two young men went out to the garden together and sat on the long bamboo bench in the shade of a tall laurel tree. The sun was sliding down the polished leaves. The white daisies among the grass were trembling.
es_translation: —Naturalness is also affectation, and the most irritating one I know —exclaimed Lord Henry, bursting into laughter. The two young people went out together to the garden, settling on a wide bamboo bench placed in the shade of a laurel tree. The sunlight slid over the waxed leaves. White daisies trembled on the grass.

en: “I do not, Harry.”
vi: “Tôi không biết đâu, Harry.”
tr: “Bilmiyorum, Harry.
es: —No lo sé, Harry.
vi_translation: “I don't know, Harry.”
tr_translation: “I don't know, Harry.”
es_translation: —I don't know, Harry.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “And what is that?” he asked.
vi: Huân tước Henry cười. “Và nó là cái gì vậy?” y hỏi.
tr: Lord Henry güldü. “Bu giz ne ola ki?” diye sordu.
es: Lord Henry rió. — Y, ¿cuál es ...? —preguntó.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed. "And what is it?" he asked.
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed. “What could this mystery be?” he asked.
es_translation: Lord Henry laughed. — And, what is ...? —he asked.

en: “I will tell you,” said Hallward; but an expression of perplexity came over his face.
vi: “Tôi sẽ kể anh nghe,” Hallward nói; nhưng một nét bối rối lướt ngang qua mặt y.
tr: Hallward, “Söyleyeyim,” dediyse de yüzünde bir şaşkınlık ifadesi belirmişti.
es: —Te lo voy a decir —respondió Hallward; pero lo que apareció en su rostro fue una expresión de perplejidad.
vi_translation: “I will tell you,” Hallward said; but a look of confusion crossed his face.
tr_translation: Hallward said, "I will tell you," but a look of astonishment had appeared on his face.
es_translation: —I am going to tell you —replied Hallward; but what appeared on his face was an expression of perplexity.

en: Lord Henry smiled, and leaning down, plucked a pink-petalled daisy from the grass and examined it. “I am quite sure I shall understand it,” he replied, gazing intently at the little golden, white-feathered disk, “and as for believing things, I can believe anything, provided that it is quite incredible.”
vi: Huân tước Henry cười và cúi xuống bứt một bông cúc cánh hồng khỏi cỏ, ngắm nghía nó. “Tôi chắc chắn là tôi có thể hiểu nó,” y đáp lại, nhìn chăm chú vào cái nhụy vàng nhỏ phủ đầy lông tơ trắng, “và về phần những điều đáng tin, tôi có thể tin mọi điều, miễn là nó hoàn toàn không thể tin nổi.”
tr: Lord Henry gülümseyerek eğildi, çimenlerin arasından pembe bir papatya kopardı, incelemeye girişti. Elindeki bu altın gözlü küçük yuvarlağa dikkatle bakarak, “Anlayacağımdan hiç kuşkum yok,” dedi. “İnanmaya gelince; ben her şeye inanabilirim, yeter ki tümden inanılmaz bir şey olsun.
es: Lord Henry sonrió y, agachándose, arrancó de entre el césped una margarita de pétalos rosados y se puso a examinarla. —Estoy seguro de que lo entenderé —replicó, contemplando fijamente el pequeño disco dorado con plumas blancas—; y en cuanto a creer cosas, me puedo creer cualquiera con tal de que sea totalmente increíble.
vi_translation: Lord Henry smiled and bent down to pluck a pink-petaled daisy from the grass, examining it. “I am sure I can understand it,” he replied, staring intently at the small yellow center covered with white fuzz, “and as for the believable things, I can believe anything, as long as it is utterly unbelievable.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled and bent down, plucked a pink daisy from the grass, and began to examine it. Looking carefully at this small round flower with a golden eye in his hand, he said, "I have no doubt that I will understand." "As for believing; I can believe anything, as long as it is something utterly unbelievable."
es_translation: Lord Henry smiled and, bending down, plucked a pink-petaled daisy from the grass and began to examine it. —I am sure I will understand it —he replied, staring intently at the small golden disc with white feathers—; and as for believing things, I can believe anything as long as it is totally unbelievable.

en: “Yes; she is a peacock in everything but beauty,” said Lord Henry, pulling the daisy to bits with his long nervous fingers.
vi: “Vâng; bà ấy là một con công trên mọi phương diện ngoại trừ sắc đẹp,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa bứt bông cúc thành nhiều mảnh bằng những ngón tay dài, bồn chồn của mình.
tr: Lord Henry, papatyayı o uzun, duyarlı parmaklarıyla didik didik ederek, “Evet, güzelliği dışında her şeyiyle tavuskuşudur,” dedi.
es: —Sí; es un pavo real en todo menos en la belleza —dijo lord Henry, deshaciendo la margarita con sus largos dedos nerviosos.
vi_translation: "Yes; she is a peacock in everything but beauty," said Lord Henry, tearing a daisy into pieces with his long, restless fingers.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, plucking the daisy with his long, sensitive fingers, said, "Yes, he is a peacock in everything but beauty."
es_translation: —Yes; he is a peacock in everything except beauty —said Lord Henry, undoing the daisy with his long, nervous fingers.

en: “My dear old Basil, you are much more than an acquaintance.”
vi: “Bạn già Basil yêu quý của tôi, anh hơn hẳn người quen.
tr: “Çok sevgili dostum Basil, bir tanıştan çok ötedesin sen.
es: —Mi querido Basil: eres mucho más que un conocido.
vi_translation: “My dear old friend Basil, you are far superior to mere acquaintances.”
tr_translation: “My very dear friend Basil, you are much more than an acquaintance.”
es_translation: —My dear Basil: you are much more than an acquaintance.

en: “Then why won’t you exhibit his portrait?” asked Lord Henry.
vi: “Vậy sao anh lại không trưng bày bức chân dung cậu ấy?” Huân tước Henry hỏi.
tr: Lord Henry, “Öyleyse onun portresini neden sergilemiyorsun?” diye sordu.
es: —Entonces, ¿por qué te niegas a exponer su retrato? —preguntó lord Henry.
vi_translation: “Then why don't you display his portrait?” Lord Henry asked.
tr_translation: Lord Henry asked, "Then why don't you exhibit his portrait?"
es_translation: —Then, why do you refuse to exhibit his portrait? —asked Lord Henry.

en: “Where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.”
vi: “Nơi tôi nghe được cái tên của Dorian Gray.” “Là ở đâu vậy?” Hallward hỏi, hơi cau mày.
tr: “Dorian Gray’in adını nerede duymuş olduğum.
es: —De dónde he oído el nombre de Dorian Gray.
vi_translation: “The place where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.”
tr_translation: "Where I might have heard the name Dorian Gray.""
es_translation: —Where have I heard the name Dorian Gray.

en: “I am very glad you didn’t, Harry.”
vi: “Tôi rất mừng là anh không biết, Harry à.”
tr: “Bilmediğine çok sevindim, Harry.
es: —Me alegro mucho de que no fuese así, Harry.
vi_translation: “I am very glad you don't know, Harry.”
tr_translation: "I'm very glad you didn't know, Harry."
es_translation: —I'm very glad it wasn't like that, Harry.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir,” said the butler, coming into the garden.
vi: “Mít-tơ Dorian Gray ở trong xưởng vẽ, thưa ông,” quản gia vừa nói vừa đi vào vườn.
tr: “mr Dorian Gray stüdyodalar, efendim.” Erkek uşak bahçede belirmişti.
es: —El señor Dorian Gray está en el estudio —anunció el mayordomo, entrando en el jardín.
vi_translation: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir," the butler said as he walked into the garden.
tr_translation: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir." The male servant had appeared in the garden.
es_translation: —Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio —announced the butler, entering the garden.

en: “You must introduce me now,” cried Lord Henry, laughing.
vi: “Anh phải giới thiệu tôi ngay,” huân tước Henry kêu lớn và cười vang.
tr: Lord Henry gülerek, “Şimdi artık beni tanıştırmak zorundasın!” dedi.
es: —Ahora tienes que presentármelo —exclamó lord Henry, riendo.
vi_translation: “You must introduce me at once,” Lord Henry exclaimed and laughed heartily.
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed, "Now you have to introduce me!" he said.
es_translation: —Now you have to introduce him to me —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing.

en: “That entirely depends on how you sit to-day, Dorian.”
vi: “Chuyện ấy phụ thuộc hoàn toàn vào việc hôm nay cậu ngồi làm mẫu ra sao đấy, Dorian.
tr: “Her şey senin bana bugün yapacağın modelliğe bağlı, Dorian.
es: —Eso depende de cómo poses hoy, Dorian.
vi_translation: "That entirely depends on how well you sit for the modeling today, Dorian."
tr_translation: "Everything depends on the modeling you will do for me today, Dorian."
es_translation: —That depends on how you pose today, Dorian.

en: “Oh, I will make your peace with my aunt. She is quite devoted to you. And I don’t think it really matters about your not being there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits down to the piano, she makes quite enough noise for two people.”
vi: “Ồ, tôi sẽ dàn hòa cho anh với dì tôi. Bà ấy rất hết lòng vì anh. Và tôi không nghĩ rằng lại có vấn đề gì thật sự nghiêm trọng với chuyện anh không đến đấy. Thính giả chắc có lẽ nghĩ đó là bản song tấu. Mỗi khi dì Agatha ngồi xuống dương cầm thì bà ấy thường gây ồn đủ cho hai người.”
tr: “Ben sizin aranızı bulurum. Halam sizi çok seviyor. Sizin kulübe gitmeyişinizin de bir şey değiştirmiş olacağını hiç sanmıyorum. Orada bulunanlar söylenenin düet olduğunu sanmışlardır zaten. Agatha Halam piyano başına geçti mi iki kişilik şamata yapar.
es: —Yo me encargo de reconciliarlo con ella. Siente verdadera devoción por usted. Y no creo que importara que no fuese. El público pensó probablemente que era un dúo. Cuando tía Agatha se sienta al piano hace ruido suficiente por dos personas.
vi_translation: “Oh, I will reconcile you with my aunt. She is very devoted to you. And I don't think there's really any serious issue with you not going there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. Whenever Aunt Agatha sits down at the piano, she usually makes enough noise for two people.”
tr_translation: “I will mediate between you. My aunt likes you very much. I don't think your not going to the club would have changed anything. Those present there probably thought it was a duet anyway. When my Aunt Agatha sits at the piano, she makes a racket for two.”
es_translation: —I will take care of reconciling him with her. She feels true devotion for you. And I don't think it would matter if you didn't go. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits at the piano, she makes enough noise for two people.

en: “That is very horrid to her, and not very nice to me,” answered Dorian, laughing.
vi: “Nói thế thì thật quá đáng với bà ấy, và cũng không hay ho gì cho lắm với tôi,” Dorian bật cười, đáp lại.
tr: Dorian gülerek, “Halanıza hakaret bu, bana da övgü sayılmaz,” dedi.
es: —Eso es una insidia contra ella y tampoco me deja a mí en muy buen lugar —respondió Dorian, riendo.
vi_translation: “Saying that would be too harsh on her, and not very nice for me either,” Dorian laughed, responding.
tr_translation: Dorian laughed, "That's an insult to your aunt, and not much of a compliment to me," he said.
es_translation: —That is an insinuation against her and it doesn't leave me in a very good position either —replied Dorian, laughing.

en: “Just turn your head a little more to the right, Dorian, like a good boy,” said the painter, deep in his work and conscious only that a look had come into the lad’s face that he had never seen there before.
vi: “Phiền cậu quay đầu một chút về bên phải, Dorian, làm ơn,” họa sỹ nói, đắm chìm vào công việc, và chỉ nhận thấy rằng một nét nào đó mà y chưa từng thấy trước đây vừa hiện lên trên gương mặt chàng trai.
tr: Ressam, “Dorian, başını birazcık daha sağa çevir, bir zahmet,” dedi. Çalışmasına iyice dalmıştı, yine de delikanlının yüzünde bundan önce görmemiş olduğu bir ifadenin belirdiğini fark ediyordu.
es: —Vuelve la cabeza un poquito más hacia la derecha, Dorian, como un buen chico —dijo el pintor, enfrascado en su trabajo, sólo consciente de que en el rostro del muchacho había aparecido una expresión completamente nueva.
vi_translation: “Please turn your head a little to the right, Dorian, please,” the artist said, immersed in his work, and only noticed that a certain feature he had never seen before had just appeared on the young man's face.
tr_translation: The painter said, "Dorian, turn your head a little more to the right, please." He was deeply engrossed in his work, yet he noticed that an expression he had never seen before appeared on the young man's face.
es_translation: —Turn your head a little more to the right, Dorian, like a good boy —said the painter, engrossed in his work, only aware that a completely new expression had appeared on the boy's face.

en: For nearly ten minutes he stood there, motionless, with parted lips and eyes strangely bright. He was dimly conscious that entirely fresh influences were at work within him. Yet they seemed to him to have come really from himself. The few words that Basil’s friend had said to him—words spoken by chance, no doubt, and with wilful paradox in them—had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before, but that he felt was now vibrating and throbbing to curious pulses.
vi: Suốt gần mười phút, cậu đứng đó, bất động, với đôi môi hé mở và cặp mắt sáng lạ lùng. Cậu đã lờ mờ nhận ra rằng những ảnh hưởng hoàn toàn mới mẻ đang khuấy động trong mình. Song cậu thấy dường như chúng thật sự đến từ bên trong cậu. Vài lời mà anh bạn của Basil vừa nói với cậu — những lời được nói tình cờ, không có gì phải nghi ngờ, cùng sự nghịch biện cố ý bên trong chúng — đã chạm vào sợi dây bí mật nào đó chưa từng được chạm đến trước đây, nhưng mà lúc này cậu cảm thấy như đang rung lên và đập theo những nhịp hiếu kỳ.
tr: Hemen hemen on dakika orada hareketsiz durdu, dudakları aralık, gözlerinde tuhaf bir parlaklık. İçindeki yepyeni kıpırtıları hayal meyal sezinliyordu, gene de bunlar kendi içinden gelmiş gibiydi. Basil’in arkadaşının söylemiş olduğu şu birkaç söz –rastgele söylenmiş sözler, hiç kuşkusuz, kasıtlı çelişkilerle dolu– genç adamın içinde gizli bir tele dokunmuştu. Şimdiye değin el değmemiş olan bu telin şimdi garip bir nabız vuruşuyla titreşimler yaparak attığını duyumsuyordu Dorian.
es: Durante cerca de diez minutos siguió allí, inmóvil, los labios abiertos y un brillo extraño en la mirada. Era vagamente consciente de que influencias completamente nuevas actuaban en su interior, aunque, le parecía a él, procedían en realidad de sí mismo. Las pocas palabras que el amigo de Basil le había dicho, palabras lanzadas al azar, sin duda, y caprichosamente paradójicas, habían tocado alguna cuerda secreta, nunca pulsada anteriormente, pero que sentía ahora vibrar y palpitar con peculiares estremecimientos.
vi_translation: For nearly ten minutes, he stood there, motionless, with slightly parted lips and strangely bright eyes. He vaguely realized that entirely new influences were stirring within him. Yet he felt as if they truly came from inside him. A few words that Basil's friend had just said to him — words spoken casually, undoubtedly, with intentional paradox within them — had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before, but now he felt it vibrating and beating with curious rhythms.
tr_translation: He stood there almost motionless for about ten minutes, his lips parted, a strange brightness in his eyes. He vaguely sensed the brand-new stirrings within him, yet they seemed to have come from within himself. The few words Basil's friend had spoken –words said at random, undoubtedly filled with deliberate contradictions– had touched a hidden chord within the young man. Dorian now felt this chord, which had remained untouched until now, vibrating with a strange pulse.
es_translation: For about ten minutes he remained there, motionless, his lips parted and a strange gleam in his eyes. He was vaguely aware that completely new influences were at work within him, although, it seemed to him, they actually came from himself. The few words that Basil's friend had said to him, words thrown out at random, no doubt, and whimsically paradoxical, had touched some secret chord, never before struck, but which he now felt vibrating and throbbing with peculiar tremors.

en: “My dear fellow, I am so sorry. When I am painting, I can’t think of anything else. But you never sat better. You were perfectly still. And I have caught the effect I wanted—the half-parted lips and the bright look in the eyes. I don’t know what Harry has been saying to you, but he has certainly made you have the most wonderful expression. I suppose he has been paying you compliments. You mustn’t believe a word that he says.”
vi: “Bạn yêu ơi, tôi xin lỗi. Khi tôi vẽ, tôi không thể nghĩ về chuyện gì khác. Nhưng cậu chưa bao giờ ngồi làm mẫu tốt hơn. Cậu bất động một cách hoàn hảo. Và tôi đã tóm được cái ấn tượng mà tôi muốn — đôi môi hé mở, nét rạng ngời trong mắt. Tôi không biết Harry đã nói gì với cậu, nhưng anh ấy chắc chắn đã làm cho cậu có được sự diễn cảm tuyệt vời nhất. Tôi cho là anh ấy đã khen ngợi cậu. Cậu không nên tin dẫu chỉ một lời mà anh ấy nói.”
tr: “Sevgili yavrum, çok üzgünüm. Resim yaparken başka hiçbir şey düşünemiyorum da. Ama hiç böyle güzel poz vermemiştin bana. Hiç kıpırdamadan durdun. Tam da istediğim ifadeyi yakaladım: Yarı aralık dudaklarla parlayan gözler. Harry sana neler söyledi, bilmiyorum ama, doğrusu yüzüne nefis bir ifade vermesini bildi. Sana iltifatlar etmiş olsa gerek. Sözlerinin hiçbirine inanma.
es: —Tendrás que perdonarme. Cuando pinto me olvido de todo lo demás. Pero nunca habías posado mejor. Has estado completamente inmóvil. Y he captado el efecto que quería: los labios entreabiertos, y el brillo en los ojos. No sé qué te habrá dicho Harry para conseguir esta expresión maravillosa. Imagino que te halagaba la vanidad. No debes creer una sola palabra de lo que diga.
vi_translation: "My dear, I'm sorry. When I draw, I can't think about anything else. But you've never sat as a better model. You were perfectly still. And I captured the impression I wanted — the slightly parted lips, the radiance in the eyes. I don't know what Harry said to you, but he certainly brought out the best expression in you. I suppose he complimented you. You shouldn't believe a single word he says."
tr_translation: “My dear child, I am very sorry. When I am painting, I can't think of anything else. But you have never posed so beautifully for me. You stood completely still. I captured exactly the expression I wanted: glowing eyes with slightly parted lips. I don't know what Harry told you, but he certainly managed to give your face a wonderful expression. He must have paid you compliments. Don't believe a word he says.”
es_translation: —You will have to forgive me. When I paint, I forget everything else. But you have never posed better. You have been completely still. And I have captured the effect I wanted: the slightly parted lips, and the sparkle in the eyes. I don't know what Harry might have told you to achieve this wonderful expression. I imagine he was flattering your vanity. You must not believe a single word he says.

en: “Yes,” continued Lord Henry, “that is one of the great secrets of life—to cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul. You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you know, just as you know less than you want to know.”
vi: “Vâng,” huân tước Henry nói tiếp, “đó là một trong những bí mật lớn nhất của cuộc sống — chữa lành linh hồn bằng cách dùng các giác quan, và chữa lành các giác quan bằng cách dùng linh hồn. Cậu là một tạo vật tuyệt vời. Cậu biết nhiều hơn là cậu nghĩ cậu biết, đúng như cậu biết ít hơn là cậu muốn biết.
tr: Lord Henry, “Evet,” diye konuşmasını sürdürdü. “Yaşamın en büyük gizlerinden biridir: ruhu duyular yoluyla, duyuları da ruh yoluyla şifaya kavuşturmak. Siz harika bir yapıtsınız. Sandığınızdan daha çok bilginiz var; öte yandan bilmek istediğinizden daha azını biliyorsunuz.
es: —Sí —prosiguió lord Henry—; ése es uno de los grandes secretos de la vida: curar el alma por medio de los sentidos, y los sentidos con el alma. Usted es una criatura asombrosa. Sabe más de lo que cree saber, pero menos de lo que quiere.
vi_translation: “Yes,” Lord Henry continued, “that is one of the great secrets of life — to heal the soul by means of the senses, and to heal the senses by means of the soul. You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you know, just as you know less than you want to know.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry continued his speech, "Yes," he said. "It is one of the great mysteries of life: to cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul. You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you do; on the other hand, you know less than you want to know."
es_translation: —Yes —continued Lord Henry—; that is one of the great secrets of life: to cure the soul by means of the senses, and the senses by means of the soul. You are an astonishing creature. You know more than you think you know, but less than you want to.

en: “What can it matter?” cried Dorian Gray, laughing, as he sat down on the seat at the end of the garden.
vi: “Chuyện ấy thì cũng có ý nghĩa gì đâu?” Dorian Gray vừa cười vừa la lên trong lúc cậu ngồi xuống chiếc ghế cuối vườn.
tr: Dorian Gray, “Ne önemi olabilir ki?” diye gülerek bahçenin sonundaki sıraya oturdu.
es: —¿Qué importancia tiene eso? —exclamó Dorian Gray, riendo, mientras se sentaba en un banco al fondo del jardín.
vi_translation: “What does that matter anyway?” Dorian Gray exclaimed with a laugh as he sat down on the chair at the end of the garden.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray, laughing, sat on the bench at the end of the garden and said, "What does it matter?"
es_translation: —What importance does that have? —exclaimed Dorian Gray, laughing, as he sat on a bench at the back of the garden.

en: Dorian Gray listened, open-eyed and wondering. The spray of lilac fell from his hand upon the gravel. A furry bee came and buzzed round it for a moment. Then it began to scramble all over the oval stellated globe of the tiny blossoms. He watched it with that strange interest in trivial things that we try to develop when things of high import make us afraid, or when we are stirred by some new emotion for which we cannot find expression, or when some thought that terrifies us lays sudden siege to the brain and calls on us to yield. After a time the bee flew away. He saw it creeping into the stained trumpet of a Tyrian convolvulus. The flower seemed to quiver, and then swayed gently to and fro.
vi: Dorian Gray lắng nghe, mắt mở to kinh ngạc. Cành tử đinh hương rơi từ tay cậu lên cỏ. Một con ong lù xù bay đến và vo ve vòng quanh một lát. Sau đó nó bắt đầu bò khắp quả bầu dục lấm chấm đầy sao hoa tí hon. Cậu ngắm nhìn nó với sự thích thú kỳ lạ ấy với những thứ tầm thường mà ta vẫn cố bày tỏ mỗi khi những thứ quan trọng khiến ta sợ hãi, hoặc khi ta bị xao lòng bởi xúc cảm nào đó mới mẻ mà ta không thể tìm được cách diễn đạt, hoặc khi ý tưởng nào đó làm ta kinh hãi bỗng dưng vây hãm não ta và kêu gọi ta đầu hàng. Một lát sau con ong bay đi. Cậu nhìn nó bò vào trong chiếc kèn trôm-pét hoen ố của một cây bìm bìm màu tím hoàng gia. Đóa hoa dường như run rẩy, rồi nhè nhẹ lắc lư.
tr: Dorian gözlerini açmış şaşkın, dalgın dinliyordu. Elindeki leylak yerdeki çakıl taşlarının üstüne düştü. Tüylü bir arı geldi, bir an leylağın üzerinde vızıldadı. Sonra minik çiçeklerden oluşmuş yıldız tutamının üzerine tırmandı. Dorian arıyı, önemli şeylerin bizi korkuttuğu, adını koyamadığımız yepyeni bir duygunun içimizde kıpırdadığı ya da bize dehşet veren bir düşüncenin ansızın beynimizi kuşatarak bize teslim ol çağrısı yaptığı zamanlarda önemsiz şeylere karşı duymaya çalıştığımız o tuhaf ilgiyle seyrediyordu. Arının mor bir kahkahaçiçeğinin parlak renkli borazanının içine sokulduğunu gördü. Çiçek şöyle bir titredi sanki, sonra usulca öne arkaya sallanmaya başladı.
es: Dorian Gray escuchaba, los ojos muy abiertos, asombrado. El ramillete de lilas se le cayó al suelo. Una sedosa abeja zumbó a su alrededor por un instante. Luego empezó a trepar con dificultad por los globos estrellados de cada flor. Dorian Gray la observó con el extraño interés por las cosas triviales que tratamos de fomentar cuando las más importantes nos asustan, o cuando nos embarga alguna nueva emoción que no sabemos expresar, o cuando alguna idea que nos aterra pone repentino sitio a la mente y exige nuestra rendición. Al cabo de algún tiempo la abeja alzó el vuelo. Dorian Gray la vio introducirse en la campanilla de una enredadera. La flor pareció estremecerse y luego se balanceó suavemente hacia adelante y hacia atrás.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide with astonishment. The lilac branch fell from his hand onto the grass. A fuzzy bee flew over and buzzed around for a moment. Then it began to crawl all over the star-speckled oval gourd. He watched it with that strange fascination we often show for trivial things when important matters frighten us, or when we are distracted by some new emotion we cannot find words to express, or when some terrifying idea suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. A moment later, the bee flew away. He watched it crawl into the tarnished trumpet of a royal purple morning glory. The flower seemed to tremble, then gently sway.
tr_translation: Dorian opened his eyes, listening in a dazed and bewildered manner. The lilac in his hand fell onto the pebbles on the ground. A fuzzy bee came and buzzed over the lilac for a moment. Then it climbed onto the tuft of star-shaped tiny flowers. Dorian watched the bee with that strange interest we try to feel towards insignificant things when important things frighten us, when a brand-new feeling we cannot name stirs within us, or when a thought that terrifies us suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. He saw the bee burrow into the bright-colored trumpet of a purple laughing flower. The flower seemed to shiver slightly, then began to gently sway back and forth.
es_translation: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide open, astonished. The bouquet of lilacs fell to the ground. A silky bee buzzed around him for a moment. Then it began to climb laboriously over the star-shaped globes of each flower. Dorian Gray watched it with the strange interest in trivial things that we try to cultivate when the more important ones frighten us, or when we are overwhelmed by some new emotion that we do not know how to express, or when some idea that terrifies us suddenly besieges the mind and demands our surrender. After some time, the bee took flight. Dorian Gray saw it enter the bell of a vine flower. The flower seemed to shudder and then gently swayed back and forth.

en: Lord Henry came over and examined the picture. It was certainly a wonderful work of art, and a wonderful likeness as well.
vi: Huân tước Henry lại gần và xem kỹ bức tranh. Nó đúng là một tác phẩm nghệ thuật phi thường, và sự tương đồng cũng phi thường.
tr: Lord Henry geldi, resmi gözden geçirdi. Hiç kuşkusuz, olağanüstü bir sanat ürünüydü, modelin tıpkısıydı.
es: Lord Henry se acercó a examinar el retrato. Era, sin duda, una espléndida obra de arte, y el parecido era excelente.
vi_translation: Lord Henry approached and examined the painting closely. It was indeed an extraordinary piece of art, and the resemblance was also remarkable.
tr_translation: Lord Henry arrived and examined the portrait. Without a doubt, it was an extraordinary work of art, exactly like the model.
es_translation: Lord Henry approached to examine the portrait. It was, without a doubt, a splendid work of art, and the likeness was excellent.

en: “Of course he likes it,” said Lord Henry. “Who wouldn’t like it? It is one of the greatest things in modern art. I will give you anything you like to ask for it. I must have it.”
vi: “Đương nhiên là cậu ấy thích nó rồi,” huân tước Henry nói. “Ai mà không thích nó cơ chứ? Nó là một trong những tác phẩm vĩ đại nhất của nghệ thuật hiện đại. Tôi sẽ đưa anh bất cứ thứ gì anh muốn đòi cho nó. Tôi phải có nó.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Elbette beğendi,” dedi. “Kim beğenmez bunu? Çağdaş sanatın en büyük yapıtlarından biri. Sana ne istersen veririm bu resme karşılık. Benim olmalı bu.
es: —Claro que le gusta —dijo lord Henry—. ¿A quién podría no gustarle? Es una de las grandes obras del arte moderno. Te daré por él lo que quieras pedirme. Debe ser mío.
vi_translation: “Of course he likes it,” said Lord Henry. “Who wouldn't like it? It is one of the greatest works of modern art. I will give you anything you want for it. I must have it.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Of course he liked it." "Who wouldn't like this? It's one of the greatest works of contemporary art. I'll give you whatever you want in exchange for this painting. It must be mine."
es_translation: —Of course he likes it —said Lord Henry—. Who could not like it? It is one of the great works of modern art. I will give you whatever you want for it. It must be mine.

en: “I stayed when you asked me,” was Lord Henry’s answer.
vi: “Tôi đã ở lại khi anh xin tôi,” là câu trả lời của huân tước Henry.
tr: Lord Henry, “Rica ettiğinde kaldım,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —Me quedé cuando me lo pediste —fue la respuesta de lord Henry.
vi_translation: “I stayed when you asked me,” was Lord Henry's reply.
tr_translation: Lord Henry replied, "I stayed when you asked."
es_translation: —I stayed when you asked me to —was Lord Henry's reply.

en: “I am glad you appreciate my work at last, Dorian,” said the painter coldly when he had recovered from his surprise. “I never thought you would.”
vi: “Tôi vui vì rốt cuộc cậu đã đánh giá cao tác phẩm của tôi, Dorian,” họa sỹ nói, lạnh lùng, khi y trấn tĩnh lại sau cơn bất ngờ. “Tôi không bao giờ nghĩ là cậu lại thế.”
tr: Ressam, şaşkınlığı geçtiği zaman soğuk soğuk, “Sonunda yaptığım resmin değerini bilmene sevindim, Dorian,” dedi. “Hiç bilmeyeceksin sanmıştım.
es: —Me alegro de que por fin aprecies mi obra, Dorian —dijo fríamente el pintor, una vez recuperado de la sorpresa—. Había perdido la esperanza.
vi_translation: "I am glad that you have finally appreciated my work, Dorian," the artist said coldly, as he calmed down after the surprise. "I never thought you would."
tr_translation: When the painter's astonishment passed, he said coldly, "I'm glad you finally appreciate the value of the painting I made, Dorian." "I thought you would never know.""
es_translation: —I'm glad that you finally appreciate my work, Dorian —said the painter coldly, once he had recovered from the surprise—. I had lost hope.

en: “You know the picture is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it existed.”
vi: “Cậu biết là bức tranh là của cậu mà, Dorian. Tôi đã tặng nó cho cậu trước khi nó tồn tại.”
tr: “Bu resim senin, Dorian, biliyorsun. Daha ortada yokken verdim onu sana.
es: —Ya sabes que el cuadro es tuyo, Dorian. Te lo di antes de que existiera.
vi_translation: "You know the painting is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it even existed."
tr_translation: "This painting is yours, Dorian, you know that. I gave it to you before it even existed."
es_translation: —You know that the painting is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it even existed.

en: “And you know you have been a little silly, Mr. Gray, and that you don’t really object to being reminded that you are extremely young.”
vi: “Và cậu biết cậu từng là một thằng bé ngờ nghệch, mít-tơ Gray, và rằng cậu không thật sự cảm thấy khó chịu vì bị nhắc rằng cậu cực kỳ trẻ.”
tr: “Biraz saçma davrandığınızı da biliyorsunuz mr Gray. Çok genç olduğunuzun vurgulanmasına da itirazınız yok aslında.
es: —Y también sabe usted, señor Gray, que se ha dejado llevar por los sentimientos y que en realidad no le parece mal que se le recuerde cuán joven es.
vi_translation: “And you know you used to be a naive boy, Mr. Gray, and that you don't really feel upset about being reminded that you are extremely young.”
tr_translation: “You also know that you are acting a bit silly, Mr. Gray. You actually have no objection to the emphasis on your youth.”
es_translation: —And you also know, Mr. Gray, that you have let yourself be carried away by your feelings and that, in reality, you do not mind being reminded of how young you are.

en: “Let us go to the theatre to-night,” said Lord Henry. “There is sure to be something on, somewhere. I have promised to dine at White’s, but it is only with an old friend, so I can send him a wire to say that I am ill, or that I am prevented from coming in consequence of a subsequent engagement. I think that would be a rather nice excuse: it would have all the surprise of candour.”
vi: “Đêm nay ta đi xem hát đi,” huân tước Henry nói. “Chắc phải có gì đó đang diễn, ở đâu đó. Tôi đã hứa dùng bữa ở chỗ White, nhưng chỉ với một anh bạn cũ, nên tôi có thể đánh một bức điện cho y để báo rằng tôi ốm, hoặc rằng tôi bị ngăn cản không đến được do một lời mời đến sau. Tôi nghĩ rằng đó sẽ là lời xin lỗi khá hay: nó sẽ có tất cả sự bất ngờ thẳng thắn.
tr: Lord Henry, “Tiyatroya gidelim bu gece,” dedi. “Bir yerlerde bir şeyler vardır elbet. White’ta akşam yemeği sözüm var çok eski bir dostumla. Hasta olduğumu ya da bir işim çıktığını söylerim. Böyle bir özür ileri sürmek çok hoş olur, bence: Açıksözlülüğün sürprizini yaratır.
es: —Vayamos esta noche al teatro —propuso lord Henry—. Habrá algo que ver en algún sitio. He quedado para cenar en White's, pero sólo se trata de un viejo amigo, de manera que le puedo mandar un telegrama diciendo que estoy enfermo o que no puedo ir en razón de un compromiso ulterior. Creo que sería una excusa bastante simpática, ya que contaría con la sorpresa de la sinceridad.
vi_translation: “Let's go watch a play tonight,” Lord Henry said. “There must be something showing, somewhere. I had promised to have dinner at White's, but it's just with an old friend, so I can send him a telegram saying that I'm ill, or that I'm prevented from coming due to a later invitation. I think that would be a rather good excuse: it will have all the straightforward surprise.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Let's go to the theater tonight." "There must be something going on somewhere. I have a dinner appointment at White's with a very old friend. I'll tell him that I'm sick or that something came up. It would be very pleasant to offer such an excuse, I think: It creates the surprise of candor."
es_translation: —Let's go to the theater tonight —proposed Lord Henry—. There will be something to see somewhere. I have a dinner appointment at White's, but it's just with an old friend, so I can send him a telegram saying that I'm sick or that I can't go due to a prior commitment. I think it would be a rather nice excuse, as it would come with the surprise of sincerity.

en: “It is such a bore putting on one’s dress-clothes,” muttered Hallward. “And, when one has them on, they are so horrid.”
vi: “Thật là chán ngán khi phải bận lễ phục,” Hallward lẩm bẩm. “Và, khi người ta bận chúng vào người, họ mới kinh khủng làm sao.”
tr: Hallward, “Resmi kılık giymek öyle can sıkıcı ki!” diye söylendi. “Giyince üstte de öyle kötü duruyor ki.
es: —¡Es tan aburrido ponerse de etiqueta! —murmuró Hallward—. Y, cuando ya lo has hecho, ¡se tiene un aspecto tan horroroso!
vi_translation: “It is really tedious to have to wear formal attire,” Hallward muttered. “And, when people put them on, they look so dreadful.”
tr_translation: Hallward grumbled, "Wearing formal attire is so annoying!" "And it looks so bad when you put it on."
es_translation: —It's so boring to dress formally! —murmured Hallward—. And, once you've done it, you look so awful!

en: “Yes,” answered Lord Henry dreamily, “the costume of the nineteenth century is detestable. It is so sombre, so depressing. Sin is the only real colour-element left in modern life.”
vi: “Đúng rồi,” huân tước Henry nói, mơ màng, “trang phục thế kỷ mười chín thật đáng tởm. Nó quá u sầu, quá chán chường. Tội lỗi là yếu tố sắc màu chân thật duy nhất còn lại trong đời sống hiện đại.”
tr: Lord Henry dalgın dalgın, “Evet,” diye yanıtladı. “On dokuzuncu yüzyılın kılığı gerçekten iğrenç. Öylesine iç karartıcı, öyle karamsar ki! Bugünün yaşantısına renk katan tek şey olarak günah kaldı.
es: —Sí —respondió lord Henry distraídamente—, la ropa del siglo XIX es detestable. Tan sombría, tan deprimente. El pecado es el único elemento de color que queda en la vida moderna.
vi_translation: “That's right,” Lord Henry said dreamily, “nineteenth-century clothing is truly disgusting. It is too gloomy, too dreary. Sin is the only real color left in modern life.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry replied absentmindedly, "Yes." "The attire of the nineteenth century is truly disgusting. So dreary, so gloomy! The only thing that adds color to today's life is sin."
es_translation: —Yes —replied Lord Henry distractedly—, the clothing of the 19th century is detestable. So gloomy, so depressing. Sin is the only element of color left in modern life.

en: The painter bit his lip and walked over, cup in hand, to the picture. “I shall stay with the real Dorian,” he said, sadly.
vi: Họa sỹ cắn môi và đi, với tách trong tay, tới chỗ bức tranh. “Tôi sẽ ở lại với Dorian thật,” y nói, buồn rầu.
tr: Ressam, dudağını dişleyerek, elinde çay bardağıyla resmin yanına gitti. Üzgün bir sesle, “Ben de gerçek Dorian Gray’le kalıyorum,” dedi.
es: El pintor se mordió el labio y, con la taza en la mano, se acercó al cuadro. —Me quedaré con el verdadero Dorian —dijo tristemente.
vi_translation: The painter bit his lip and walked, with a cup in hand, towards the painting. "I will stay with Dorian indeed," he said, sorrowfully.
tr_translation: The painter, biting his lip, went to the painting with a tea glass in his hand. In a sad voice, he said, "I am also staying with the real Dorian Gray."
es_translation: The painter bit his lip and, with the cup in his hand, approached the painting. —I will stay with the real Dorian —he said sadly.

en: “At least you are like it in appearance. But it will never alter,” sighed Hallward. “That is something.”
vi: “Chí ít thì cậu cũng giống nó bên ngoài. Nhưng nó sẽ chẳng bao giờ thay đổi,” Hallward thở dài. “Thế mới quý.”
tr: Hallward, “Yani görünüş olarak böylesin. Hem de bu resim hiç değişmeyecek,” diye göğüs geçirdi. “Bu da bir şeydir.
es: —Tienes al menos el mismo aspecto. Pero él no cambiará —suspiró Hallward—. Eso es algo.
vi_translation: "At least you resemble it on the outside. But it will never change," Hallward sighed. "That's what makes it precious."
tr_translation: Hallward, "So this is how you look. And this picture will never change," he sighed. "That's something."
es_translation: —You at least look the same. But he won't change —sighed Hallward—. That's something.

en: “Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.”
vi: “Vì tôi đã hứa với huân tước Henry Wotton là sẽ đi với anh ấy.”
tr: “Lord Henry Wotton’la gitmeye söz verdim de ondan.
es: —Porque he prometido a lord Henry Wotton ir con él.
vi_translation: “Because I promised Lord Henry Wotton that I would go with him.”
tr_translation: “I promised to go with Lord Henry Wotton, that's why.”
es_translation: —Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.

en: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head.
vi: Dorian Gray cười và lắc đầu.
tr: Dorian Gray gülerek başını olmaz anlamında salladı.
es: Dorian Gray rió y negó con la cabeza.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray smiled and shook his head.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head with a laugh, indicating no.
es_translation: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head.

en: The lad hesitated, and looked over at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea-table with an amused smile.
vi: Chàng trai lưỡng lự và liếc nhìn huân tước Henry, còn y thì theo dõi họ từ bàn trà với một nụ cười thích thú.
tr: Delikanlı duraksadı; çay masasının başından onları bıyık altından gülümseyerek seyretmekte olan Lord Henry’ye baktı.
es: El muchacho vaciló y miró hacia lord Henry, que los contemplaba desde la mesita del té con una sonrisa divertida.
vi_translation: The young man hesitated and glanced at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea table with a delighted smile.
tr_translation: The young man hesitated; he looked at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the head of the tea table with a sly smile.
es_translation: The boy hesitated and looked towards Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea table with an amused smile.

en: “No, of course not,” cried Dorian.
vi: “Không, đương nhiên là không,” Dorian kêu lên.
tr: Dorian, “Ne münasebet, elbette unutmam,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —¡No, claro que no! —exclamó Dorian.
vi_translation: “No, of course not,” Dorian exclaimed.
tr_translation: Dorian replied, "What do you mean, of course I won't forget."
es_translation: —No, of course not! —exclaimed Dorian.

en: “Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get something out of you.”
vi: “Tình cảm gia đình thuần khiết thôi, cháu cam đoan với chú thế, chú George ạ. Cháu muốn nhờ chú việc này.”
tr: “İnanın bana, George Amca, beni buraya getiren salt akraba sevgisidir. Sizden bir şey koparmak istiyorum da!
es: —Puro afecto familiar, tío George, te lo aseguro. Quiero pedirte algo.
vi_translation: “It's just pure family affection, I assure you of that, Uncle George.” “I want to ask you for this favor.”
tr_translation: “Believe me, Uncle George, it is purely familial love that brought me here. I want to get something from you!”
es_translation: —Pure familial affection, Uncle George, I assure you. I want to ask you something.

en: “Money, I suppose,” said Lord Fermor, making a wry face. “Well, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that money is everything.”
vi: “Tiền hả, chú nghĩ vậy,” huân tước Fermor nói, làm mặt nhăn. “Nào, ngồi xuống và kể hết cho chú nghe về nó. Thanh niên ngày nay cứ tưởng tiền là tất cả.
tr: Lord Fermor, “Para olsa gerek,” diye yüzünü buruşturdu. “Her neyse, otur da anlat bakalım. Zamane gençleri hayatta her şeyin para olduğunu sanıyorlar.
es: —Dinero, imagino —respondió lord Fermor, torciendo el gesto—. Bueno; siéntate y cuéntamelo todo. En estos tiempos que corren los jóvenes se imaginan que el dinero lo es todo.
vi_translation: "Money, you think so," Lord Fermor said, making a face. "Now, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people today think money is everything."
tr_translation: Lord Fermor grimaced, "It must be about money," he said. "Anyway, sit down and tell me about it. Young people these days think that money is everything in life."
es_translation: —Money, I imagine —responded Lord Fermor, twisting his expression—. Well; sit down and tell me everything. These days, young people imagine that money is everything.

en: “He is very good-looking,” assented Lord Henry.
vi: “Cậu ấy rất đẹp,” huân tước Henry tán thành.
tr: Lord Henry, “Çok yakışıklı,” diye amcasını doğruladı.
es: —Es bien parecido —asintió lord Henry.
vi_translation: “He is very beautiful,” Lord Henry agreed.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "Very handsome," he confirmed his uncle.
es_translation: —He is quite handsome —agreed Lord Henry.

en: Lord Henry shook his head. “American girls are as clever at concealing their parents, as English women are at concealing their past,” he said, rising to go.
vi: Huân tước Henry lắc đầu. “Gái Mỹ cũng giỏi trong việc giấu cha mẹ như phụ nữ Anh trong việc giấu quá khứ,” y vừa nói vừa đứng dậy định đi.
tr: Lord Henry başını salladı. “İngiliz kadınları geçmişlerini saklamakta nasıl ustaysalar, Amerikalı kızlar da ana babalarını saklamakta o denli kurnaz oluyorlar,” diyerek gitmek üzere ayağa kalktı.
es: Lord Henry negó con la cabeza. —Las jóvenes americanas son tan inteligentes para esconder a sus padres como las mujeres inglesas para ocultar su pasado —dijo lord Henry, levantándose para marcharse.
vi_translation: Lord Henry shook his head. "American girls are just as good at hiding things from their parents as English women are at hiding their past," he said as he stood up to leave.
tr_translation: Lord Henry nodded his head. “While English women are adept at hiding their pasts, American girls are equally cunning at hiding their parents,” he said, standing up to leave.
es_translation: Lord Henry shook his head. —American young women are as clever at hiding things from their parents as English women are at concealing their past —said Lord Henry, getting up to leave.

en: “How dreadful!” exclaimed Lady Agatha. “Really, some one should interfere.”
vi: “Khiếp thật!” Bà Agatha la lên. “Thật sự là ai đó nên can thiệp.
tr: Leydi Agatha, “Ne feci!” diye bağırdı. “Biri çıkıp engellemeli.
es: —¡Qué espanto! —exclamó lady Agatha—. Alguien debería tomar cartas en el asunto.
vi_translation: “How terrifying!” Mrs. Agatha exclaimed. “Someone really should intervene.”
tr_translation: Lady Agatha shouted, "What have I done!" "Someone must stop this."
es_translation: —What a fright! —exclaimed Lady Agatha—. Someone should take action on this matter.

en: “I am told, on excellent authority, that her father keeps an American dry-goods store,” said Sir Thomas Burdon, looking supercilious.
vi: “Tôi nghe nói, theo một nguồn hết sức tin cậy, là cha cô ấy quản lý một tiệm tạp hóa bên Mỹ,” ngài Thomas Burdon nói, trông có vẻ khinh khỉnh.
tr: Sir Thomas Burdon kibirli bir ifadeyle, “Güvenilir bir yerden duyduğuma göre kızın babası Amerika’da manifatura dükkânı işletiyormuş,” diye konuştu.
es: —Me han informado, de muy buena tinta, que su padre tiene un almacén de áridos —dijo sir Thomas Burdon con aire desdeñoso.
vi_translation: "I heard, according to a very reliable source, that her father manages a grocery store in America," said Mr. Thomas Burdon, looking disdainful.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas Burdon said with a haughty expression, "I have heard from a reliable source that the girl's father runs a dry goods store in America."
es_translation: —I have been reliably informed that his father owns a gravel warehouse —said Sir Thomas Burdon disdainfully.

en: “My uncle has already suggested pork-packing, Sir Thomas.”
vi: “Chú tôi đã đưa ra giả thuyết là buôn thịt lợn, thưa ngài Thomas.
tr: Sir Thomas Burdon kibirli bir ifadeyle, “Güvenilir bir yerden duyduğuma göre kızın babası Amerika’da manifatura dükkânı işletiyormuş,” diye konuştu.
es: —Mi tío ha sugerido y a que se trata de chacinería, sir Thomas.
vi_translation: “My uncle hypothesized that it was pork trading, Sir Thomas.”
tr_translation: Sir Thomas Burdon said with a haughty expression, "I have heard from a reliable source that the girl's father runs a dry goods store in America."
es_translation: —My uncle has suggested that it is about charcuterie, Sir Thomas.

en: “American novels,” answered Lord Henry, helping himself to some quail.
vi: “Các tiểu thuyết Mỹ,” huân tước Henry trả lời, tự mời mình một chút chim cun cút.
tr: Lord Henry tabağına biraz bıldırcın alarak, “Amerikan romanları,” diye karşılık verdi.
es: —Novelas americanas —respondió lord Henry, mientras se servía una codorniz.
vi_translation: “American novels,” Lord Henry replied, helping himself to a bit of quail.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, taking some quail onto his plate, responded, "American novels."
es_translation: —American novels —replied Lord Henry, while serving himself a quail.

en: “Don’t mind him, my dear,” whispered Lady Agatha. “He never means anything that he says.”
vi: “Đừng để ý đến nó, bạn ơi,” bà Agatha thì thào. “Nó chẳng bao giờ nghiêm túc với những gì mà nó nói ra.”
tr: Leydi Agatha, “Sen ona bakma, cicim,” diye fısıldadı. “Onun hiçbir sözünü ciddiye almamak gerekir.
es: —No le haga caso, querida —susurró lady Agatha—. Mi sobrino nunca habla en serio.
vi_translation: "Don't pay attention to it, my friend," whispered Mrs. Agatha. "It is never serious about what it says."
tr_translation: Lady Agatha whispered, "Don't pay attention to her, darling." "You shouldn't take any of her words seriously."
es_translation: —Don't pay attention to him, dear —whispered Lady Agatha—. My nephew never speaks seriously.

en: “Perhaps, after all, America never has been discovered,” said Mr. Erskine; “I myself would say that it had merely been detected.”
vi: “Không chừng rốt cuộc thì châu Mỹ chưa bao giờ được phát hiện ra,” mít-tơ Erskine nói. “Tự tôi vẫn nói là nó chỉ được nhận ra mà thôi.”
tr: mr Erskine, “Belki de Amerika hiç keşfedilmedi aslında,” dedi. “Bana sorarsanız yalnızca ortaya çıkarıldı.
es: —Quizá, después de todo, América nunca haya sido descubierta —dijo el señor Erskine—; yo diría más bien que fue meramente detectada.
vi_translation: “Perhaps in the end, America was never actually discovered,” Mr. Erskine said. “I always say it was merely recognized.”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine said, "Perhaps America was never actually discovered." "If you ask me, it was only revealed."
es_translation: —Perhaps, after all, America was never truly discovered —said Mr. Erskine—; I would rather say it was merely detected.

en: “They go to America,” murmured Lord Henry.
vi: “Họ đi Mỹ,” huân tước Henry thì thào.
tr: Lord Henry, “Amerika’ya,” diye mırıldandı.
es: —Van a los Estados Unidos —murmuró lord Henry.
vi_translation: “They go to America,” Lord Henry whispered.
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "To America."
es_translation: —They are going to the United States —murmured Lord Henry.

en: “But must we really see Chicago in order to be educated?” asked Mr. Erskine plaintively. “I don’t feel up to the journey.”
vi: “Nhưng liệu ta có thật sự cần phải trông thấy Chicago để mà được giáo dục?” mít-tơ Erskine hỏi lại, rầu rĩ. “Tôi không thấy đủ sức cho hành trình ấy.”
tr: mr Erskine, “İyi de, eğitilmek için ille Chicago’ya gitmek zorunda mıyız?” diye sızlandı. “Ben böyle bir yolu göze alamıyorum şahsen.
es: —¿De verdad tenemos que ver Chicago para estar bien educados? —preguntó el señor Erskine quejumbrosamente—. No me siento capaz de emprender ese viaje.
vi_translation: “But do we really need to see Chicago to be educated?” Mr. Erskine asked again, gloomily. “I don't feel up to that journey.”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine complained, "But do we really have to go to Chicago to get an education?" "Personally, I can't take such a risk."
es_translation: —Do we really have to see Chicago to be well-educated? —asked Mr. Erskine querulously—. I don't feel capable of undertaking that trip.

en: “How dreadful!” cried Lord Henry. “I can stand brute force, but brute reason is quite unbearable. There is something unfair about its use. It is hitting below the intellect.”
vi: “Đáng sợ thật!’ huân tước Henry kêu lên. “Tôi có thể chống lại sức mạnh tàn bạo, nhưng lý trí tàn bạo thì đúng là không chịu nổi. Có gì đó gian lận trong việc sử dụng nó. Nó đánh vào dưới trí tuệ.
tr: Lord Henry, “Ne feci!” dedi. “Mutlak güce katlanabilirim ama mutlak mantık hiç çekilmez. Böyle bir şeyin kullanımında bir haksızlık bulurum ben. Kafanın belden aşağısına vurmak sayarım.
es: —¡Terrible! —exclamó lord Henry—. No me gusta la fuerza bruta, pero la razón bruta es totalmente insoportable. No está bien utilizarla. Es como golpear por debajo del intelecto.
vi_translation: “How terrifying!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “I can resist brute force, but brute reason is truly unbearable. There is something deceitful in its use. It strikes below the intellect.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "I didn't do it!" he said. "I can endure absolute power, but absolute logic is unbearable. I find an injustice in the use of such a thing. I consider it a blow below the belt."
es_translation: —Terrible! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. I do not like brute force, but brute reason is absolutely unbearable. It is not right to use it. It is like hitting below the intellect.

en: “I do not understand you,” said Sir Thomas, growing rather red.
vi: “Tôi không hiểu cậu,” ngài Thomas nói, mặt trở nên khá đỏ.
tr: Sir Thomas, yüzü biraz kızararak, “Sizi anlamıyorum,” dedi.
es: —No le entiendo —dijo sir Thomas, enrojeciendo considerablemente.
vi_translation: “I don't understand you,” Mr. Thomas said, his face becoming quite red.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas, with his face slightly reddening, said, "I don't understand you."
es_translation: —I don't understand you —said Sir Thomas, blushing considerably.

en: “I can sympathize with everything except suffering,” said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders. “I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with the colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life’s sores, the better.”
vi: “Cháu có thể thông cảm với mọi điều, ngoại trừ sự đau khổ,” huân tước Henry nói, nhún vai. “Cháu không thế thông cảm với điều ấy được. Nó quá xấu xí, quá kinh khủng, quá buồn thảm. Có gì đó hết sức bệnh hoạn trong sự thông cảm tân thời với nỗi đau. Người ta nên thông cảm với sắc màu, vẻ đẹp, niềm vui sống. Càng ít nói về những đớn đau phiền muộn của cuộc đời thì càng tốt.”
tr: Lord Henry omuz silkerek, “Dünyada her şeye karşı anlayışlı davranabilirim, acı çekmek dışında,” dedi. “İşte buna anlayış gösteremem. Gereğinden fazla çirkin, feci, üzücüdür. Çağımızın acıya karşı gösterdiği yakınlıkta son derece hastalıklı bir şeyler var. İnsan yaşamın rengine, güzelliğine, yaşam sevincine yakınlık göstermelidir. Yaşamın cerahatli yaralarından ne kadar konuşmazsak o kadar iyi bence.
es: —Soy capaz de simpatizar con cualquier cosa menos con el sufrimiento —dijo lord Henry, encogiéndose de hombros—. Hasta eso no llego. Es demasiado feo, demasiado horrible, demasiado angustioso. Hay algo terriblemente morboso en la simpatía de nuestra época por el dolor. Debemos interesarnos por los colores, por la belleza, por la alegría de vivir. Cuanto menos se hable de las miserias de la vida, tanto mejor.
vi_translation: “I can sympathize with everything except suffering,” said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders. “I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid about modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with color, beauty, the joy of life. The less said about the sorrows and woes of life, the better.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry shrugged, "I can sympathize with everything in the world except suffering," he said. "That is something I cannot sympathize with. It is excessively ugly, tragic, and distressing. There is something extremely morbid in our age's affinity for pain. One should show affinity for the color, beauty, and joy of life. The less we talk about life's festering wounds, the better, in my opinion."
es_translation: —I can sympathize with anything except suffering —said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders—. I can't go that far. It's too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid about our era's sympathy for pain. We should be interested in colors, in beauty, in the joy of living. The less we talk about the miseries of life, the better.

en: “Still, the East End is a very important problem,” remarked Sir Thomas with a grave shake of the head.
vi: “Tuy nhiên, East End là một vấn đề hệ trọng,” ngài Thomas nhận xét, với một cái lắc đầu nghiêm nghị.
tr: Sir Thomas başını ciddilikle sallayarak, “Gene de East End çok önemli bir sorun,” dedi.
es: —De todos modos, el East End es un problema muy importante —señaló sir Thomas, con un grave movimiento de cabeza.
vi_translation: “However, the East End is a serious matter,” Sir Thomas remarked, with a solemn shake of his head.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas shook his head seriously and said, "Nevertheless, the East End is a very important issue."
es_translation: —In any case, the East End is a very important problem —remarked Sir Thomas, with a grave nod of his head.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “I don’t desire to change anything in England except the weather,” he answered. “I am quite content with philosophic contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt through an over-expenditure of sympathy, I would suggest that we should appeal to science to put us straight. The advantage of the emotions is that they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it is not emotional.”
vi: Huân tước Henry cười. “Tôi không mong muốn thay đổi bất cứ thứ gì ở Anh ngoài thời tiết,” y trả lời. “Tôi khá là thỏa mãn với sự suy ngẫm về triết học. Nhưng, do thế kỷ mười chín đã vỡ nợ vì chi tiêu quá tay cho sự thương cảm, thành thử tôi đề nghị là ta nên thỉnh cầu Khoa học đưa ta về chính đạo. Lợi thế của các cảm xúc là ở chỗ chúng dẫn ta đi lạc, còn lợi thế của Khoa học là ở chỗ nó không có cảm xúc.”
tr: Lord Henry güldü. “Ben İngiltere’de havadan başka hiçbir şeyi değiştirmek istemiyorum,” diye karşılık verdi. “Felsefî düşüncelere dalmak bana yetiyor. Şu var ki, on dokuzuncu yüzyıl bizim anlayış ve acımamızı har vurup harman savurmamız yüzünden iflas ettiğine göre benim önerim, bizi düzeltmesi için bilime başvurmamızdır. Duyguların avantajı şudur ki bizi yolumuzdan saptırırlar; bilimin avantajıysa duygusal olmamasındadır.
es: Lord Henry se echó a reír. —No deseo cambiar nada en Inglaterra, a excepción del clima —respondió—. Me basta y me sobra con la contemplación filosófica. Pero como el siglo XIX se ha arruinado por un excesivo gasto de simpatía, sugiero que se acuda a la ciencia para solucionarlo. La ventaja de las emociones es que nos llevan por el mal camino, y la ventaja de la ciencia es que excluye la emoción.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed. “I do not wish to change anything in England except the weather,” he replied. “I am quite satisfied with philosophical contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt from overspending on sympathy, I suggest that we should appeal to Science to bring us back to the right path. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray, while the advantage of Science is that it has no emotions.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed. “There is nothing I want to change in England except the weather,” he replied. “Delving into philosophical thoughts is enough for me. The fact is, since the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt due to our reckless squandering of understanding and compassion, my suggestion is that we turn to science to correct us. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray; the advantage of science is that it is not emotional.”
es_translation: Lord Henry laughed. —I do not wish to change anything in England, except the weather —he replied—. I am more than satisfied with philosophical contemplation. But since the 19th century has been ruined by an excessive expenditure of sympathy, I suggest turning to science to solve it. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it excludes emotion.

en: “But we have such grave responsibilities,” ventured Mrs. Vandeleur timidly.
vi: “Nhưng ta mang những trách nhiệm hết sức trầm trọng,” bà Vandeleur đánh bạo, bẽn lẽn.
tr: ms Vandeleur çekinerek, “Ama öylesine ağır ve ciddi sorumluluklar taşıyoruz ki!” diye bir görüş ortaya attı.
es: —Pero tenemos gravísimas responsabilidades —aventuró tímidamente la señora Uandeleur.
vi_translation: “But I bear very grave responsibilities,” Mrs. Vandeleur ventured, shyly.
tr_translation: Ms. Vandeleur hesitantly suggested, "But we bear such heavy and serious responsibilities!"
es_translation: —But we have very serious responsibilities —ventured Mrs. Uandeleur timidly.

en: “Terribly grave,” echoed Lady Agatha.
vi: “Trầm trọng khủng khiếp,” bà Agatha lặp lại.
tr: “Son derece ağır ve ciddi,” diye Leydi Agatha onun sözlerini tekrarladı.
es: —Sumamente graves -se hizo eco lady Agatha.
vi_translation: "Terribly serious," Mrs. Agatha repeated.
tr_translation: “Extremely serious and grave,” Lady Agatha repeated his words.
es_translation: —Extremely serious - echoed Lady Agatha.

en: “Ah! that is very nice, and very wrong of you,” she cried; “so mind you come”; and she swept out of the room, followed by Lady Agatha and the other ladies.
vi: “À! Thế rất dễ thương và cũng rất sai từ phía anh đấy,” bà kêu lên; “vậy anh nhớ đến nhé;” và bà lướt nhanh ra khỏi phòng, theo sau là bà Agatha và các bà khác.
tr: Düşes, “Ah, çok şeker, çok ayıp!” dedi. “Bekliyorum, öyleyse. Böyle diyerek tüm tantanasıyla salondan çıktı. Leydi Agatha ile öbür hanımlar da peşinden gittiler.
es: —¡Ah! ¡Muy amable y muy cruel por su parte! —exclamó la duquesa—; pero no se olvide de venir —y abandonó la habitación seguida por lady Agatha y las otras damas.
vi_translation: "Ah! That is very charming and also very wrong on your part," she exclaimed; "so remember that;" and she quickly glided out of the room, followed by Mrs. Agatha and the other ladies.
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "Oh, very sweet, very shameful!" "I am waiting, then." With that, he left the room with all his fuss. Lady Agatha and the other ladies followed him.
es_translation: —Ah! Very kind and very cruel of you! —exclaimed the Duchess—; but don't forget to come —and she left the room followed by Lady Agatha and the other ladies.

en: “I fear you are right,” answered Mr. Erskine. “I myself used to have literary ambitions, but I gave them up long ago. And now, my dear young friend, if you will allow me to call you so, may I ask if you really meant all that you said to us at lunch?”
vi: “Tôi sợ là anh đúng,” mít-tơ Erskine trả lời. “Tự tôi từng có khát vọng văn chương, nhưng đã gác chúng lại từ lâu lắm rồi. Và giờ đây, anh bạn trẻ thân mến của tôi, nếu anh sẽ cho phép tôi gọi anh thế, liệu tôi có thể hỏi là anh có thật sự nghiêm túc về tất cả những gì anh vừa nói với chúng tôi vào bữa trưa hay không?”
tr: mr Erskine, “Korkarım haklısınız,” dedi. “Ben de bir zamanlar edebiyatla ilgili emeller beslerdim, ama yıllar önce vazgeçtim. Şimdi de... İzin verirseniz size genç dostum diyeyim... Yemekte söylediklerinizin hepsinde ciddi miydiniz?
es: —Me temo que tiene usted razón —respondió el señor Erskine—. Yo mismo tuve ambiciones literarias, pero las abandoné hace mucho. Y ahora, mi joven y querido amigo, si me permite que le dé ese nombre, ¿le puedo preguntar si mantiene usted todo lo que nos ha dicho durante el almuerzo?
vi_translation: “I'm afraid you are right,” Mr. Erskine replied. “I once had literary aspirations myself, but I set them aside long ago. And now, my dear young friend, if you will allow me to call you that, may I ask if you were truly serious about everything you said to us at lunch?”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine said, "I'm afraid you're right." "I once had literary ambitions myself, but I gave them up years ago. And now... If you allow me to call you my young friend... Were you serious about everything you said at dinner?"
es_translation: —I am afraid you are right —replied Mr. Erskine—. I myself had literary ambitions, but I abandoned them long ago. And now, my young and dear friend, if you allow me to call you that, may I ask if you stand by everything you told us during lunch?

en: “I quite forget what I said,” smiled Lord Henry. “Was it all very bad?”
vi: “Tôi quên sạch những gì tôi nói rồi,” huân tước Henry cười. “Có phải chúng xấu cả không?”
tr: Lord Henry, “Neler dediğimi unuttum gitti,” diye gülümsedi. “Çok mu kötü şeyler söyledim?
es: —He olvidado por completo lo que he dicho —sonrió lord Henry—. ¿Tan inmoral era?
vi_translation: “I have completely forgotten what I said,” Lord Henry laughed. “Were they all bad?”
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled, "I have completely forgotten what I said." "Did I say very bad things?"
es_translation: —I have completely forgotten what I said —smiled Lord Henry—. Was it so immoral?

en: Lord Henry laughed and rose. “I am going to the park,” he cried.
vi: Huân tước Henry cười và đứng dậy. “Tôi đi công viên đây,” y kêu lên.
tr: Lord Henry gülerek ayağa kalktı. “Ben parka gidiyorum,” dedi.
es: Lord Henry rió, poniéndose en pie. —Me voy al parque —exclamó.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed and stood up. "I'm going to the park," he exclaimed.
tr_translation: Lord Henry stood up laughing. "I am going to the park," he said.
es_translation: Lord Henry laughed, standing up. —I'm going to the park —he exclaimed.

en: As he was passing out of the door, Dorian Gray touched him on the arm. “Let me come with you,” he murmured.
vi: Lúc y đi qua cửa, Dorian Gray chạm vào cánh tay y. “Cho tôi đi cùng anh,” cậu thì thầm.
tr: Kapıdan çıkarken Dorian Gray onun koluna dokundu. “İzin verin ben de sizinle geleyim,” diye mırıldandı.
es: Al atravesar la puerta, Dorian Gray le tocó en el brazo. —Permítame ir con usted —murmuró.
vi_translation: As he walked past the door, Dorian Gray touched his arm. "Let me go with you," he whispered.
tr_translation: As he was leaving through the door, Dorian Gray touched his arm. "Allow me to come with you," he murmured.
es_translation: As he passed through the door, Dorian Gray touched him on the arm. —Allow me to go with you —he murmured.

en: “Ah! I have talked quite enough for to-day,” said Lord Henry, smiling. “All I want now is to look at life. You may come and look at it with me, if you care to.”
vi: “À! Tôi đã nói khá đủ cho cả ngày hôm nay rồi,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa cười. “Tất cả những gì tôi muốn lúc này là nhìn đời. Cậu có thể đi và nhìn nó cùng tôi, nếu cậu thích.
tr: Lord Henry gülümseyerek, “Yok, bugün konuştuğum yeter de artar bile,” dedi. “Şimdi tek isteğim yaşamı seyretmek. Eğer isterseniz siz de gelip benimle birlikte seyredebilirsiniz. 1. Dönemin toplum rehberi (telefon rehberi gibi) kullanılan genel terim; sokak ağzıdır.
es: —¡Ah! Ya he hablado más que suficiente por hoy —dijo lord Henry, sonriendo—. Todo lo que quiero ahora es mirar la vida. Puede usted venir y mirarla conmigo, si lo tiene a bien.
vi_translation: "Ah! I've said quite enough for today already," Lord Henry said with a laugh. "All I want now is to observe life. You can come and observe it with me, if you like."
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled and said, "No, I've talked enough for today." "Now, my only desire is to watch life. If you want, you can come and watch it with me." 1. The general term used for the period's social guide (like a phone directory) is street slang.
es_translation: —Ah! I have already spoken more than enough for today —said Lord Henry, smiling—. All I want now is to watch life. You can come and watch it with me, if you please.

en: “I dare say, my dear,” said Lord Henry, shutting the door behind her as, looking like a bird of paradise that had been out all night in the rain, she flitted out of the room, leaving a faint odour of frangipanni. Then he lit a cigarette and flung himself down on the sofa.
vi: “Chắc vậy, em yêu,” huân tước Henry nói, khép cửa lại sau lưng cô, trong lúc, nhìn như con chim thiên đường vừa ở cả đêm ngoài mưa, cô vụt ra khỏi phòng, để lại một mùi hương hoa sứ mơ hồ. Sau đó y châm điếu thuốc và buông mình xuống xô-pha.
tr: Lord Henry, “Olabilir, iki gözüm,” diyerek kapıyı onun ardından kapadı. Kadın, bütün gece yağmurda kalmış bir Zümrüdüanka kuşu görünümüyle ardında hafif bir frangipani kokusu bırakarak odadan dışarı süzülmüştü. Kocası bir sigara yakıp kendini bir kanepeye attı.
es: —Imagino que sí, querida mía -lord Henry cerró la puerta tras ella, cuando, con el aspecto de un ave del paraíso que se hubiera pasado toda la noche bajo la lluvia, salió revoloteando de la habitación, dejando un leve olor a tarta de almendras; luego encendió un cigarrillo y se dejó caer en el sofá.
vi_translation: “Probably, my dear,” Lord Henry said, closing the door behind her, as she, looking like a bird of paradise that had spent the whole night in the rain, darted out of the room, leaving behind a faint scent of frangipani. After that, he lit a cigarette and sank into the sofa.
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Maybe, my dear," and closed the door behind her. The woman, with the appearance of a Phoenix that had been in the rain all night, glided out of the room, leaving behind a faint scent of frangipani. Her husband lit a cigarette and threw himself onto a couch.
