vi: “Tôi sẽ chỉ lối cho ông, mít-tơ Hubbard, nếu ông vui lòng theo tôi. Hoặc có lẽ tốt hơn là ông đi trước đi. Tôi sợ là nó ở ngay tầng cao nhất của ngôi nhà. Chúng ta sẽ đi lên bằng cầu thang phía trước, vì nó rộng hơn.”
tr: “Ben önünüze düşeyim, mr Hubbard; bir zahmet beni izleyin. Ya da siz önden gidin, daha iyi. Korkarım en üst kata tırmanacağız. Ön merdivenden çıkalım, daha geniştir.
es: —Le mostraré el camino, señor Hubbard, si es tan amable de seguirme. O quizá sea mejor que vaya usted delante. Mucho me temo que la habitación está en lo más alto de la casa. Iremos por la escalera principal, que es más ancha.
vi_translation: “I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you would kindly follow me. Or perhaps it would be better if you went ahead. I am afraid it is right at the top of the house. We will go up by the front stairs, as they are wider.”
tr_translation: “Let me lead the way, Mr. Hubbard; please follow me. Or you go ahead, that's better. I'm afraid we will have to climb to the top floor. Let's take the front stairs, they are wider.”
es_translation: —I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you would be so kind as to follow me. Or perhaps it would be better if you went ahead. I am very much afraid that the room is at the very top of the house. We will take the main staircase, which is wider.

en: “Bring it in, Mr. Hubbard, please,” he said, wearily, turning round. “I am sorry I kept you so long. I was thinking of something else.”
vi: “Mang nó vào đi, mít-tơ Hubbard, làm ơn,” cậu nói, mệt mỏi, quay người lại. “Tôi lấy làm tiếc là đã giữ ông lại lâu thế. Tôi đang nghĩ về chuyện khác.
tr: Genç adam arkasına dönerek yorgun bir sesle, “İçeri getirin lütfen, mr Hubbard,” dedi. “Kusura bakmayın, beklettim. Aklım başka bir şeye gitti de.
es: —Haga el favor de traerlo aquí, señor Hubbard —dijo con voz cansada, volviéndose—. Siento haberle hecho esperar tanto. Estaba pensando en otra cosa.
vi_translation: "Bring it in, Mr. Hubbard, please," he said, tiredly, turning around. "I'm sorry for keeping you so long. I was thinking about something else."
tr_translation: The young man turned around and said in a tired voice, "Bring it inside, please, Mr. Hubbard." "Sorry for keeping you waiting. My mind wandered to something else."
es_translation: —Please bring it here, Mr. Hubbard —he said in a tired voice, turning around—. I'm sorry to have kept you waiting so long. I was thinking about something else.

en: When the sound of their footsteps had died away, Dorian locked the door and put the key in his pocket. He felt safe now. No one would ever look upon the horrible thing. No eye but his would ever see his shame.
vi: Khi tiếng chân họ đã tắt, Dorian khóa cửa lại, nhét chìa vào túi. Giờ đây cậu đã thấy an toàn. Không một ai còn có lúc trông thấy thứ kinh khủng ấy nữa. Không con mắt nào ngoài mắt cậu còn có lúc được nhìn nỗi hổ thẹn của cậu nữa.
tr: Adamların ayak sesleri duyulmaz olunca Dorian kapıyı kilitleyerek anahtarı cebine koydu. Güvenlikteydi artık. O korkunç şeye bir daha hiç kimse asla bakmayacaktı. Dorian’ın utancını kendi gözlerinden başka göz asla görmeyecekti.
es: Cuando se perdió el ruido de sus pisadas, Dorian cerró la puerta y se guardó la llave en el bolsillo. Ahora se sentía seguro. Nadie volvería a contemplar a aquella horrible criatura. Ninguna mirada que no fuera la suya vería su vergüenza.
vi_translation: When their footsteps had faded, Dorian locked the door and put the key in his pocket. Now he felt safe. No one would ever see that horrible thing again. No eyes but his own would ever behold his shame again.
tr_translation: When the men's footsteps could no longer be heard, Dorian locked the door and put the key in his pocket. He was safe now. No one would ever look at that horrible thing again. No eyes other than his own would ever see Dorian's shame.
es_translation: When the sound of his footsteps faded, Dorian closed the door and put the key in his pocket. Now he felt safe. No one would ever look upon that horrible creature again. No eyes but his own would see his shame.

en: It was almost nine o’clock before he reached the club, where he found Lord Henry sitting alone, in the morning-room, looking very much bored.
vi: Đã gần chín giờ trước khi cậu đến câu lạc bộ, nơi cậu thấy huân tước Henry ngồi một mình, trong phòng khách buổi sáng, nhìn có vẻ rất chán đời.
tr: Kulübe vardığında saat dokuza geliyordu. Lord Henry’yi sabah salonunda, yalnız başına buldu. Çok sıkılmış olduğu belliydi.
es: Casi eran las nueve cuando llegó al club, donde encontró a lord Henry, solo, en una habitación que se utilizaba por las mañanas como sala de estar, con aire de infinito aburrimiento.
vi_translation: It was nearly nine o'clock before he arrived at the club, where he found Lord Henry sitting alone in the morning lounge, looking very bored.
tr_translation: It was almost nine o'clock when he reached the lodge. He found Lord Henry alone in the morning room. It was clear that he was very bored.
es_translation: It was almost nine o'clock when he arrived at the club, where he found Lord Henry alone in a room that was used in the mornings as a sitting room, with an air of infinite boredom.

en: “I didn’t say I liked it, Harry. I said it fascinated me. There is a great difference.”
vi: “Tôi không nói tôi thích nó, Harry. Tôi nói nó thôi miên tôi. Một sự khác biệt lớn đấy.”
tr: “Sevdim demedim ki, Harry. Beni sardı, dedim. Büyük ayrım var arada.
es: —No he dicho que me guste, Harry. He dicho que me fascina. Hay una gran diferencia.
vi_translation: “I didn't say I liked it, Harry. I said it mesmerized me. There's a big difference.”
tr_translation: “I didn't say I loved, Harry. I said it enveloped me. There's a big difference between the two.”
es_translation: —I didn't say I like it, Harry. I said it fascinates me. There's a big difference.

en: “Ah, you have discovered that?” murmured Lord Henry. And they passed into the dining-room.
vi: “À, cậu đã khám phá ra điều ấy sao?” huân tước Henry thì thầm. Và họ đi qua phòng ăn.
tr: Lord Henry, “Ya, bunu öğrendin demek?” diye mırıldandı. Yemek salonuna geçtiler.
es: —Ah, ¿ya has hecho ese descubrimiento? —murmuró lord Henry, mientras se dirigían hacia el comedor.
vi_translation: "Ah, you have discovered that, have you?" Lord Henry whispered. And they walked through the dining room.
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "So, you have learned this?" They moved to the dining room.
es_translation: —Ah, have you already made that discovery? —murmured Lord Henry, as they headed towards the dining room.

en: Yes: there was to be, as Lord Henry had prophesied, a new Hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having, in our own day, its curious revival. It was to have its service of the intellect, certainly, yet it was never to accept any theory or system that would involve the sacrifice of any mode of passionate experience. Its aim, indeed, was to be experience itself, and not the fruits of experience, sweet or bitter as they might be. Of the asceticism that deadens the senses, as of the vulgar profligacy that dulls them, it was to know nothing. But it was to teach man to concentrate himself upon the moments of a life that is itself but a moment.
vi: Đúng: sẽ xuất hiện, như huân tước Henry tiên đoán, một Chủ nghĩa khoái lạc mới, có thể tái tạo cuộc sống, cứu cuộc sống khỏi cái chủ nghĩa đạo đức khắc nghiệt, vô duyên đang phục hưng một cách kỳ lạ trong thời đại chúng ta. Nó nhất định sẽ viện đến sự giúp đỡ của trí tuệ; tuy nhiên nó không bao giờ chấp nhận bất cứ lý thuyết hoặc hệ thống nào đòi hỏi phải hy sinh bất cứ cách thức trải nghiệm đam mê nào. Mục đích của nó, quả thật, là bản thân sự trải nghiệm, chứ không phải các thành quả của sự trải nghiệm, dẫu chúng có ngọt ngào hay cay đắng. Về cái chủ nghĩa khổ hạnh vẫn làm dịu các giác quan, cũng như về sự trác táng tầm thường vẫn làm cùn chúng thì nó không hay biết gì. Nhưng nó dạy con người tập trung hết mình vào các khoảnh khắc của một cuộc đời mà về bản chất cũng chỉ là một khoảnh khắc.
tr: Evet: Tıpkı Lord Henry’nin tahmin ettiği gibi yeni bir hedonizm akımı gelecek ve yaşamı yeni baştan yaratacaktı; çok tuhaftır ki günümüzde yeniden hortlayan şu haşin, alımsız tutuculuktan kurtaracaktı yaşamı. Bu yeni hedonizm sırasında, düşünceden yararlanacaktı, doğallıkla. Ne var ki tutku ve heyecanlardan vazgeçilmesini gerektiren hiçbir kuram ve düzen benimsenmeyecekti. Daha doğrusu amacı doğrudan doğruya bu gibi duyuların yaşanması olacaktı, yoksa bu yaşam deneylerinin acı tatlı meyveleri değil. Duyuları donduran estetizmden de, duyuları körelten avam hovardalığından da habersiz olacaktı bu akım. İnsana, kendisi tek bir andan ibaret olan bir yaşamın anları üstünde durmayı öğretecekti.
es: Sí; tenía que haber, como lord Henry había profetizado, un nuevo hedonismo que recreara la vida, que la salvara de ese puritanismo tosco y violento que está teniendo en nuestra época un extraño renacimiento. Un hedonismo que utilizaría sin duda los servicios de la inteligencia, pero sin aceptar teoría o sistema alguno que implicara el sacrificio de cualquier modalidad de experiencia apasionada. Su objetivo, efectivamente, era la experiencia misma y no los frutos de la experiencia, tanto dulces como amargos. Prescindiría del ascetismo que sofoca los sentidos y de la vulgar desvergüenza que los embota. Pero enseñaría al ser humano a concentrarse en los instantes singulares de una vida que no es en sí misma más que un instante.
vi_translation: Correct: as Lord Henry predicted, a new Hedonism will emerge, capable of rejuvenating life, saving it from the harsh, graceless morality that is strangely reviving in our era. It will certainly seek the aid of intellect; however, it will never accept any theory or system that demands the sacrifice of any form of passionate experience. Its purpose, indeed, is the experience itself, not the fruits of the experience, whether they be sweet or bitter. As for the asceticism that dulls the senses, and the common debauchery that blunts them, it knows nothing. But it teaches man to focus entirely on the moments of a life that, in its essence, is but a moment.
tr_translation: Yes: Just as Lord Henry predicted, a new hedonism would emerge and recreate life anew; it is very strange that it would save life from the harsh, unattractive conservatism that has resurfaced today. During this new hedonism, it would naturally make use of thought. However, no theory or system that required the abandonment of passions and excitements would be adopted. Rather, its purpose would be to directly experience such sensations, not the bittersweet fruits of these life experiences. This movement would be unaware of both the aesthetism that freezes the senses and the vulgar debauchery that dulls them. It would teach people to focus on the moments of a life that consists of a single moment.
es_translation: Yes; there had to be, as Lord Henry had prophesied, a new hedonism that would recreate life, that would save it from that coarse and violent puritanism that is having a strange resurgence in our era. A hedonism that would undoubtedly use the services of intelligence, but without accepting any theory or system that implied the sacrifice of any form of passionate experience. Its objective, indeed, was the experience itself and not the fruits of the experience, both sweet and bitter. It would dispense with the asceticism that stifles the senses and the vulgar shamelessness that dulls them. But it would teach the human being to concentrate on the singular moments of a life that is in itself nothing more than a moment.

en: Of such insolences and attempted slights he, of course, took no notice, and in the opinion of most people his frank debonair manner, his charming boyish smile, and the infinite grace of that wonderful youth that seemed never to leave him, were in themselves a sufficient answer to the calumnies, for so they termed them, that were circulated about him. It was remarked, however, that some of those who had been most intimate with him appeared, after a time, to shun him. Women who had wildly adored him, and for his sake had braved all social censure and set convention at defiance, were seen to grow pallid with shame or horror if Dorian Gray entered the room.
vi: Đối với những sự xấc láo và khinh khỉnh cố tình như vậy thì cậu, dĩ nhiên, chẳng buồn để ý đến, và theo quan điểm của phần lớn mọi người thì thái độ phóng khoáng thẳng thắn của cậu, nụ cười trẻ thơ quyến rũ của cậu, và nét duyên vô tận của cái tuổi thanh xuân diệu kỳ dường như chẳng hề rời bỏ cậu, tự chúng đã là một câu trả lời đủ sức thuyết phục cho những lời vu khống, vì họ đã gọi chúng là vậy, vẫn lan truyền về cậu. Tuy nhiên, có thể thấy rõ là vài kẻ trong số những người từng thân thiết nhất với cậu, sau một thời gian, lại lảng tránh cậu. Những phụ nữ tôn sùng cậu điên cuồng, vì cậu mà bất chấp mọi chỉ trích của xã hội thượng lưu và thách thức mọi tục lệ, đã bị trông thấy tái mặt đi vì xấu hổ hoặc khiếp hãi nếu Dorian Gray vào phòng.
tr: Bu gibi küstahlıkları, saygısızlıkları Dorian umursamıyordu bile tabii. Açık yürekli, kıvrak, şen tutumları, cana yakın, çocuksu gülümseyişi ve üzerinden hiç eksilmeyen o harikulade gençliğin sonsuz tatlılığı, çoğu kimsenin gözünde onun aleyhindeki iftiraların –çünkü onlar bu söylentilere iftira diyorlardı– en yeterli yanıtıydı. Öte yandan onunla en içli dışlı olanlardan kimilerinin bir süre sonra ondan kaçındıkları da dikkati çekiyordu. Ona çılgınca vurularak onun uğruna toplumun olanca kınamasını göğüslemiş, geleneklere meydan okumuş kadınların, onun odaya girmesiyle ya utançtan ya da dehşetten sapsarı kesildikleri görülüyordu.
es: Dorian Gray, por supuesto, no prestaba la menor atención a tales insolencias y desprecios deliberados y, en opinión de la mayoría, su naturalidad y su aire jovial, su encantadora sonrisa adolescente y la gracia infinita de la maravillosa juventud que parecía no abandonarle nunca, eran por sí solas respuesta suficiente a las calumnias, porque así las calificaba la mayoría, que circulaban acerca de él. Se señalaba, de todos modos, que algunas de las personas con las que había tenido un trato más íntimo parecían, al cabo de algún tiempo, evitarlo. Mujeres que manifestaron hacia él una adoración sin limites, que desafiaron por él la censuró de la sociedad y que prescindieron de todas las convenciones, palidecían de vergüenza y horror si Dorian Gray entraba en el salón donde se encontraban.
vi_translation: For such deliberate insolence and disdain, he, of course, didn't bother to pay attention, and in the view of most people, his straightforward and generous attitude, his charming boyish smile, and the endless charm of his marvelous youth, which seemed never to leave him, were in themselves a persuasive enough answer to the slanders, as they called them, that continued to spread about him. However, it was clear that some of those who had been closest to him, after a while, began to avoid him. The women who worshipped him madly, defying all high society's criticisms and challenging all conventions for his sake, were seen to turn pale with shame or fear if Dorian Gray entered the room.
tr_translation: Dorian didn't even care about such insolence and disrespect, of course. The open-hearted, agile, cheerful attitudes, the friendly, childlike smile, and the endless sweetness of that marvelous youth that never faded from him were, in the eyes of many, the most sufficient response to the slanders against him – because they called these rumors slander. On the other hand, it was noticeable that some of those who were most intimate with him started to avoid him after a while. It was observed that women who had fallen madly in love with him, who had faced all the condemnation of society for his sake, and who had defied traditions, turned pale either from shame or horror when he entered the room.
es_translation: Dorian Gray, of course, paid no attention whatsoever to such insolences and deliberate scorns and, in the opinion of most, his naturalness and jovial air, his charming adolescent smile and the infinite grace of the wonderful youth that seemed never to abandon him, were in themselves a sufficient response to the slanders, because that is how most people described them, that circulated about him. It was noted, however, that some of the people with whom he had had a more intimate relationship seemed, after some time, to avoid him. Women who showed towards him an unlimited adoration, who defied society's censure for him and disregarded all conventions, would pale with shame and horror if Dorian Gray entered the room where they were.

en: Yet these whispered scandals only increased in the eyes of many his strange and dangerous charm. His great wealth was a certain element of security. Society—civilized society, at least—is never very ready to believe anything to the detriment of those who are both rich and fascinating. It feels instinctively that manners are of more importance than morals, and, in its opinion, the highest respectability is of much less value than the possession of a good chef. And, after all, it is a very poor consolation to be told that the man who has given one a bad dinner, or poor wine, is irreproachable in his private life. Even the cardinal virtues cannot atone for half-cold entrées, as Lord Henry remarked once, in a discussion on the subject, and there is possibly a good deal to be said for his view. For the canons of good society are, or should be, the same as the canons of art. Form is absolutely essential to it. It should have the dignity of a ceremony, as well as its unreality, and should combine the insincere character of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays delightful to us. Is insincerity such a terrible thing? I think not. It is merely a method by which we can multiply our personalities.
vi: Tuy nhiên những tai tiếng ấy chỉ làm gia tăng, trong mắt nhiều người, sự quyến rũ lạ kỳ và nguy hiểm của cậu. Tài sản lớn của cậu cũng là một yếu tố an toàn nhất định. Xã hội, chí ít là xã hội văn minh, chẳng bao giờ sẵn lòng tin vào bất cứ điều gì làm phương hại đến những kẻ vừa giàu vừa hấp dẫn. Nó cảm nhận theo bản năng là thái độ quan trọng hơn đức hạnh, và, theo quan điểm nó, tư cách đáng tôn trọng nhất cũng ít giá trị hơn nhiều so với việc có đầu bếp giỏi. Và, rốt cuộc thì ta cũng chẳng được an ủi là bao khi nghe bảo rằng cái người đã cho ta một bữa tối tồi tàn, hoặc món rượu tệ hại, lại không thể chê trách được trong đời tư. Thậm chí lòng tốt nồng ấm cũng không thể cứu chuộc được món khai vị nguội lạnh, như huân tước Henry có lần nhận xét, trong một cuộc thảo luận về chủ đề này; và có lẽ có rất nhiều điều để nói về cách nhìn của anh ấy. Bởi lẽ các tiêu chuẩn của một xã hội tốt cũng giống, hoặc nên giống, như các tiêu chuẩn nghệ thuật. Hình thái là yếu tố tuyệt đối cần thiết với nó. Nó nên có sự trang trọng cũng như tính phi thực của một nghi lễ, và nên kết hợp đặc tính không thành thực của một vở kịch lãng mạn với sự hóm hỉnh và vẻ đẹp khiến những vở kịch như vậy thành ra thú vị với chúng ta. Sự không thành thực có phải là một thứ khủng khiếp đến vậy không? Tôi nghĩ là không. Nó chỉ là cách giúp ta có thể nhân cá tính ta lên nhiều lần.
tr: Kulaktan kulağa fısıldanan bu skandallar, birçoklarının gözünde onun o garip, tehlikeli çekiciliğini artırmaya yarıyordu yalnızca. Büyük serveti de onun için belirli bir güven kaynağıydı. Sosyete, en azından uygar toplumların sosyetesi, hem zengin hem çekici hem de ilginç olan kişiler aleyhinde söylenenlere inanmaya asla gönüllü olmaz. Nezaket kurallarının ahlak kurallarından daha önemli olduğu konusunda içgüdüsel bir kanısı vardır ve onun görüşüne göre en büyük saygınlık bile iyi bir aşçıbaşı kullanmaktan daha az önemlidir. Öyle ya, kötü bir sofra açan, kalitesiz şarap sunan kişinin özel yaşantısında kusursuz bir insan olduğunu bilmek neye yarar? Bir gün bu konu konuşulurken Lord Henry’nin dediği üzere, baş yemeğin sofraya soğuk gelişinin günahını en üstün erdemler bile ödeyemez! Onun bu görüşünün çok yerinde olduğunu sanıyoruz. Çünkü yüksek sosyetenin temel yasalarıyla sanatın temel yasaları birdir ya da bir olmalıdır. Biçim, sosyete için kesinlikle vazgeçilmeyecek bir öğedir. Bu biçim, bir törenin saygınlığına ve asılsızlığına sahip olmalıdır ve romantik bir sahne oyununun yapmacık niteliğiyle böyle oyunları bize sevdiren kıvrak nükte ve güzelliği özünde birleştirmelidir. Yapmacıklık kötü müdür? Sanmıyorum. Kişililiklerimizi çarpıp çoğaltmamıza yarayacak bir yöntemdir yalnızca.
es: Aquellos escándalos susurrados sólo servían, sin embargo, a ojos de muchos, para acrecentar su extraño y peligroso encanto. Su gran fortuna era, indudablemente, un elemento de seguridad. La sociedad, la sociedad civilizada al menos, nunca está muy dispuesta a creer nada en detrimento de quienes son, al mismo tiempo, ricos y fascinantes. Siente, de manera instintiva, que los modales tienen más importancia que la moral y, en su opinión, la respetabilidad más acrisolada vale muchísimo menos que la posesión de un buen chef. Y, a decir verdad, consuela muy poco saber que la persona que te invita a una cena execrable o que te sirve un vino de mala calidad es irreprochable en su vida privada. Ni siquiera las virtudes cardinales justifican unas entrées semifrías, como señaló en una ocasión lord Henry en un debate sobre aquel tema; y existen sin duda excelentes razones para sostener ese punto de vista. Porque los cánones de la buena sociedad son, o deberían ser, los mismos que los cánones del arte. La forma es absolutamente esencial. La vida social debe tener la dignidad de una ceremonia, y también su irrealidad, y combinar la insinceridad de una comedia romántica con el ingenio y la belleza que la dotan de encanto para nosotros. ¿Acaso la insinceridad es una cosa tan terrible? No lo creo. Es, sencillamente, un método que nos permite multiplicar nuestras personalidades.
vi_translation: However, those scandals only increased, in the eyes of many, his strange and dangerous allure. His great wealth was also a certain safety factor. Society, at least civilized society, is never willing to believe anything that harms those who are both rich and attractive. It instinctively feels that attitude is more important than virtue, and, in its view, the most respectable character is worth far less than having a good chef. And, after all, we are hardly consoled when told that the person who gave us a lousy dinner, or terrible wine, is blameless in their private life. Even warm-hearted kindness cannot redeem a cold appetizer, as Lord Henry once remarked, in a discussion on this subject; and perhaps there is much to be said for his perspective. For the standards of a good society are, or should be, the same as those of art. Form is an absolutely necessary element for it. It should have the solemnity as well as the unreality of a ritual, and should combine the insincerity of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays enjoyable to us. Is insincerity such a terrible thing? I think not. It is merely a way to multiply our personalities.
tr_translation: The scandals whispered from ear to ear only served to increase his strange, dangerous allure in the eyes of many. His great wealth was also a certain source of security for him. Society, at least the society of civilized nations, is never willing to believe anything said against someone who is both rich, attractive, and interesting. It has an instinctive belief that the rules of courtesy are more important than the rules of morality, and in its view, even the greatest respectability is less important than employing a good chef. After all, what good is it to know that someone who sets a poor table and serves inferior wine is impeccable in their private life? As Lord Henry once said on this subject, not even the highest virtues can atone for the sin of the main course arriving cold at the table! We believe his view is very well-founded. Because the fundamental laws of high society and the fundamental laws of art are one and the same, or should be. Form is an absolutely indispensable element for society. This form must possess the dignity and insubstantiality of a ceremony and combine the artificial nature of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays endearing to us. Is artificiality bad? I don't think so. It is merely a method that allows us to multiply and diversify our personalities.
es_translation: Those whispered scandals only served, however, in the eyes of many, to heighten his strange and dangerous charm. His great fortune was, undoubtedly, an element of security. Society, at least civilized society, is never very willing to believe anything to the detriment of those who are, at the same time, rich and fascinating. It feels, instinctively, that manners are more important than morals and, in its opinion, the most unblemished respectability is worth far less than the possession of a good chef. And, to tell the truth, it is very little consolation to know that the person who invites you to an execrable dinner or serves you poor quality wine is irreproachable in their private life. Not even the cardinal virtues justify semi-cold entrées, as Lord Henry once remarked in a debate on that subject; and there are undoubtedly excellent reasons to support that point of view. Because the canons of good society are, or should be, the same as the canons of art. Form is absolutely essential. Social life should have the dignity of a ceremony, and also its unreality, and combine the insincerity of a romantic comedy with the wit and beauty that endow it with charm for us. Is insincerity such a terrible thing? I don't think so. It is, simply, a method that allows us to multiply our personalities.

en: Yet one had ancestors in literature as well as in one’s own race, nearer perhaps in type and temperament, many of them, and certainly with an influence of which one was more absolutely conscious. There were times when it appeared to Dorian Gray that the whole of history was merely the record of his own life, not as he had lived it in act and circumstance, but as his imagination had created it for him, as it had been in his brain and in his passions. He felt that he had known them all, those strange terrible figures that had passed across the stage of the world and made sin so marvellous and evil so full of subtlety. It seemed to him that in some mysterious way their lives had been his own.
vi: Mà người ta có tổ tiên trong văn chương hệt như trong nòi giống, không chừng nhiều vị trong số các tổ tiên văn chương ấy còn gần gũi hơn về kiểu người và tính khí, và chắc chắn là có một ảnh hưởng mà ta nhận thức được hoàn hảo hơn. Có những lúc mà Dorian Gray thấy cả lịch sử chỉ là hồ sơ đời cậu, không như cậu sống cuộc đời ấy bằng hành động và theo tình huống, mà như óc tưởng tượng của cậu đã tạo ra nó cho cậu, như nó ở trong não bộ và trong các đam mê của cậu. Cậu cảm thấy là cậu đã quen tất cả bọn họ, những nhân vật khủng khiếp kỳ lạ đã đi ngang qua sân khấu trần gian và làm cho tội lỗi thành ra kỳ diệu làm vậy, và cái xấu thành ra đầy tinh tế làm vậy. Cậu thấy dường như theo một lối huyền bí nào đó, đời họ đã thành đời cậu.
tr: Öte yandan kişinin soy yolundan ataları olduğu gibi edebiyat dünyasında da ataları vardı ki, bunlar tip ve huy yönünden insana ötekilerden daha yakın oluyor, insan onların etkisini daha kesin fark ediyordu. Kimi zaman Dorian’a insanlık tarihinin tümü onun yaşamöyküsünden ibaretmiş gibi geliyordu: durum ve eylemleriyle, yaşadığı gibi değil de imgeleminin onun için yarattığı gibi, beyninde, tutkularında canlandırdığı gibi. Dünya sahnesinden gelip geçmiş olan o değişik, müthiş kişilerin hepsini tanımış gibi geliyordu; günahı böylesine şahane, kötülüğü böylesine gizemli kılan o kişiler. Onların geçmişte yaşadıkları da –nasıl bilinmez– onun hayatıydı sanki.
es: Pero también se tienen antepasados literarios, además de los de la propia estirpe, muchos de ellos quizá más próximos por la constitución y el temperamento, y con una influencia de la que se era consciente con mucha mayor claridad. Había ocasiones en que a Dorian Gray le parecía que la totalidad de la historia no era más que el relato de su propia vida, no como la había vivido en sus acciones y detalles, sino como su imaginación la había creado para él, como había existido en su cerebro y en sus pasiones. Tenía la sensación de haberlas conocido a todas, a aquellas extrañas y terribles figuras que habían atravesado el gran teatro del mundo, haciendo del pecado algo tan maravilloso y del mal algo tan sutil. Le parecía que, de algún modo misterioso, sus vidas habían sido también la suya.
vi_translation: But people have ancestors in literature just as in lineage, perhaps many of these literary ancestors are even closer in type and temperament, and certainly have an influence that we can perceive more perfectly. There are times when Dorian Gray feels that all of history is merely the record of his own life, not as he lives it through actions and circumstances, but as his imagination has created it for him, as it exists in his mind and passions. He feels that he has known all of them, those terrible and strange characters who have passed through the stage of the world and made sin so marvelous, and evil so full of subtlety. He feels as if, in some mysterious way, their lives have become his own.
tr_translation: On the other hand, just as a person has ancestors from their lineage, they also have ancestors in the literary world who, in terms of type and disposition, are closer to them than the others, and one could more distinctly perceive their influence. Sometimes it seemed to Dorian as if the entirety of human history consisted solely of his own biography: with its situations and actions, not as he lived them, but as his imagination created them for him, as he envisioned them in his mind and passions. It felt as though he had known all those different, formidable individuals who had passed through the world stage; those who made sin so magnificent and evil so mysterious. It was as if their lives in the past – how, it is unknown – were his own life.
es_translation: But one also has literary ancestors, in addition to those of one's own lineage, many of whom might be closer in constitution and temperament, and with an influence that was much more clearly recognized. There were times when it seemed to Dorian Gray that the entirety of history was nothing more than the story of his own life, not as he had lived it in his actions and details, but as his imagination had created it for him, as it had existed in his mind and passions. He felt as if he had known them all, those strange and terrible figures who had traversed the great theater of the world, making sin something so marvelous and evil something so subtle. It seemed to him that, in some mysterious way, their lives had also been his own.

en: “I shall be charmed. But won’t you miss your train?” said Dorian Gray languidly as he passed up the steps and opened the door with his latch-key.
vi: “Tôi rất vui. Nhưng liệu rồi anh có bị lỡ tàu không?” Dorian Gray nói, uể oải, lúc cậu bước lên các bậc thềm và mở cửa bằng cái chìa khóa rập ngoài của mình.
tr: “Çok sevinirim ama trenini kaçırmaz mısın?” diye soran Dorian tembel tembel basamakları çıktı, anahtarıyla kapıyı açtı.
es: —Encantado. Pero, ¿no perderás el tren? —preguntó Dorian Gray lánguidamente, mientras subía los escalones de la entrada y abría la puerta con su llave.
vi_translation: "I am very happy." "But will you miss the train?" Dorian Gray said languidly, as he stepped up the stairs and opened the door with his latchkey.
tr_translation: “I would be very happy, but won't you miss your train?” asked Dorian as he lazily climbed the steps and opened the door with his key.
es_translation: —Delighted. But, won't you miss the train? —asked Dorian Gray languidly, as he climbed the entrance steps and opened the door with his key.

en: “What is it all about?” cried Dorian in his petulant way, flinging himself down on the sofa. “I hope it is not about myself. I am tired of myself to-night. I should like to be somebody else.”
vi: “Thế nó liên quan đến chuyện gì?” Dorian la lên, theo cái lối nóng nảy của mình, và buông mình xuống xô-pha. “Tôi mong nó không liên quan đến tôi. Tôi mệt với chính tôi đêm nay. Tôi những muốn biến thành ai đó khác.
tr: Dorian huysuzlanarak, “Neymiş konuşacağın?” diye sordu. “Benimle ilgili değildir, umarım. Bu gece kendi kendimden bıkmış durumdayım. Bir başkası olmak istiyorum.
es: —¿De qué se trata? —exclamó Dorian, sin esconder su irritación, dejándose caer en el sofá—. Espero que no tenga nada que ver conmigo. Esta noche estoy cansado de mí mismo. Me gustaría ser otra persona.
vi_translation: “So what does it have to do with?” Dorian exclaimed, in his usual impatient manner, and threw himself onto the sofa. “I hope it has nothing to do with me. I am tired of myself tonight. I wish I could become someone else.”
tr_translation: Dorian asked sulkily, "What is it that you want to talk about?" "I hope it is not about me. I am tired of myself tonight. I want to be someone else."
es_translation: —What is it about? —exclaimed Dorian, not hiding his irritation, as he let himself fall onto the sofa—. I hope it has nothing to do with me. Tonight I am tired of myself. I would like to be someone else.

en: “It is about yourself,” answered Hallward in his grave deep voice, “and I must say it to you. I shall only keep you half an hour.”
vi: “Nó liên quan đến cậu,” Hallward trả lời, bằng cái giọng trầm ấm từ tốn của anh, “và tôi phải nói nó với cậu. Tôi sẽ chỉ giữ cậu lại độ nửa giờ.”
tr: “Seninle ilgili.” Hallward o kalın, ciddi sesiyle karşılık verdi. “Mutlaka söylemem gerekiyor. Yalnızca yarım saatini alacağım.
es: —Se trata de ti —respondió Hallward con voz seria y resonante—, y no tengo más remedio que decírtelo. Sólo necesito media hora.
vi_translation: "It concerns you," Hallward replied, in his warm, deliberate voice, "and I must tell you about it." "I will only keep you for about half an hour."
tr_translation: "It's about you." Hallward replied in that thick, serious voice. "I absolutely must tell you. It will only take half an hour of your time."
es_translation: —It is about you —replied Hallward with a serious and resonant voice—, and I have no choice but to tell you. I only need half an hour.

en: Dorian sighed and lit a cigarette. “Half an hour!” he murmured.
vi: Dorian thở dài, châm một điếu thuốc lá. “Nửa giờ!” cậu lẩm bẩm.
tr: Dorian içini çekerek bir sigara yaktı. “Yarım saatmiş!” diye mırıldandı.
es: Dorian suspiró y encendió un cigarrillo. -¡Media hora! —murmuró.
vi_translation: Dorian sighed, lighting a cigarette. "Half an hour!" he muttered.
tr_translation: Dorian sighed and lit a cigarette. “Half an hour!” he muttered.
es_translation: Dorian sighed and lit a cigarette. "Half an hour!" he murmured.

en: “To see my soul!” muttered Dorian Gray, starting up from the sofa and turning almost white from fear.
vi: “Thấy linh hồn tôi!” Dorian Gray lẩm bẩm, đứng phắt dậy khỏi xô-pha và gần như trắng bệch đi vì sợ.
tr: Dorian Gray, “Ruhumu görmek ha!” diye söylenerek yerinden fırladı. Korkudan benzi solmuştu.
es: —¡Ver mi alma! —murmuró Dorian Gray, alzándose del sofá y palideciendo de miedo.
vi_translation: "See my soul!" Dorian Gray muttered, standing up abruptly from the sofa and almost turning pale with fear.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray, "See my soul, huh!" he muttered, jumping up from his seat. His face had turned pale with fear.
es_translation: —murmured Dorian Gray, rising from the sofa and paling with fear.

en: He turned round. “What I have to say is this,” he cried. “You must give me some answer to these horrible charges that are made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely untrue from beginning to end, I shall believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can’t you see what I am going through? My God! don’t tell me that you are bad, and corrupt, and shameful.”
vi: Y quay lại. “Điều tôi phải nói là thế này,” y la lên. “Cậu phải cho tôi câu trả lời nào đó về những lời buộc tội khủng khiếp bị đưa ra để chống lại cậu. Nếu cậu bảo tôi rằng chúng sai tuyệt đối từ đầu đến cuối, tôi sẽ tin cậu. Phủ nhận chúng đi, Dorian, phủ nhận chúng đi! Chẳng lẽ cậu không thế thấy những gì tôi phải trải qua? Chúa ơi! Đừng bảo tôi là cậu xấu xa, đồi bại, nhục nhã.”
tr: Ressam ona doğru döndü. “Söyleyeceğim şu: Sana yöneltilen bu iğrenç suçlamalar konusunda bana bir açıklamada bulunmalısın. Hepsinin baştan sona uydurma olduğunu söylersen inanacağım. Yalanla bunları, Dorian, hepsini yalanla! Neler çektiğimi gözün görmüyor mu? Ulu Tanrım, kötü yürekli, ahlaksız, rezil biri olduğunu söyleme bana!
es: El pintor se volvió. —Lo que tengo que decir es esto —exclamó—. Has de darme alguna respuesta a las terribles acusaciones que se hacen contra ti. Si me dices que son absolutamente falsas de principio a fin, te creeré. ¡Niégalas, Dorian, hazme el favor de negarlas! ¿No ves lo mucho que estoy sufriendo? ¡Dios del cielo! No me digas que eres un malvado, un corrupto, un infame.
vi_translation: He turned back. "What I have to say is this," he shouted. "You must give me some answer to these terrible accusations that have been made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely false from beginning to end, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can't you see what I have to go through? Good God! Don't tell me that you are wicked, depraved, and dishonorable."
tr_translation: The painter turned towards him. “What I have to say is this: You must give me an explanation regarding these disgusting accusations directed at you. If you tell me they are completely fabricated, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them all! Can't you see what I've been through? Good God, don't tell me you are a wicked, immoral, disgraceful person!”
es_translation: The painter turned around. —What I have to say is this —he exclaimed—. You must give me some answer to the terrible accusations made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely false from beginning to end, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, do me the favor of denying them! Don't you see how much I am suffering? Good heavens! Don't tell me that you are a wicked, corrupt, infamous person.

en: “I shall come with you, Dorian, if you wish it. I see I have missed my train. That makes no matter. I can go to-morrow. But don’t ask me to read anything to-night. All I want is a plain answer to my question.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ đi cùng cậu, Dorian, nếu cậu muốn thế. Tôi thấy tôi đã lỡ tàu. Thế cũng chẳng sao. Mai tôi có thể đi. Nhưng đừng yêu cầu tôi đọc bất cứ thứ gì đêm nay. Tất cả những gì tôi muốn chỉ là một câu trả lời thẳng thắn cho câu hỏi của tôi.”
tr: “Gelirim, Dorian, madem istiyorsun. Zaten trenim de kaçmış bu arada. Önemli değil. Yarın giderim. Yalnız bu gece hiçbir şey okutma bana. Tek istediğim soruma açık bir yanıt.
es: —Subiré contigo, Dorian, si así lo deseas. Veo que ya he perdido el tren. Da lo mismo. Saldré mañana. Pero no me pidas que lea nada esta noche. Todo lo que quiero es una respuesta directa a mi pregunta.
vi_translation: “I will go with you, Dorian, if you want that. I see that I have missed the train. That’s alright. I can go tomorrow. But don’t ask me to read anything tonight. All I want is a straightforward answer to my question.”
tr_translation: "I'll come, Dorian, since you want me to. Anyway, I've missed my train as well. It's not important. I'll go tomorrow. Just don't make me read anything tonight. All I want is a clear answer to my question."
es_translation: —I will go up with you, Dorian, if you wish. I see that I have already missed the train. It doesn't matter. I will leave tomorrow. But don't ask me to read anything tonight. All I want is a direct answer to my question.

en: “What does this mean?” cried Hallward, at last. His own voice sounded shrill and curious in his ears.
vi: “Thế này nghĩa là sao?” rốt cuộc Hallward kêu to. Giọng y vang lên lanh lảnh lạ lùng trong tai y.
tr: En sonunda Hallward, “Ne demek oluyor bu?” diye hafifçe bağırdı. Kendi sesi kendi kulağına tiz, tuhaf geldi.
es: —¿Qué significa esto? —exclamó Hallward, finalmente. Su propia voz le resultó discordante y extraña.
vi_translation: “What does this mean?” Hallward finally exclaimed. His voice sounded strangely shrill in his own ears.
tr_translation: Finally, Hallward shouted softly, "What does this mean?" His own voice sounded shrill and strange to his ears.
es_translation: —What does this mean? —exclaimed Hallward, finally. His own voice sounded discordant and strange to him.

en: “Years ago, when I was a boy,” said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, and taught me to be vain of my good looks. One day you introduced me to a friend of yours, who explained to me the wonder of youth, and you finished a portrait of me that revealed to me the wonder of beauty. In a mad moment that, even now, I don’t know whether I regret or not, I made a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer....”
vi: “Nhiều năm về trước, khi tôi còn là một cậu bé,” Dorian Gray nói, vò nát bông hoa trong tay, “anh gặp tôi, tâng bốc tôi, dạy tôi tự đắc với sắc đẹp của mình. Một ngày nọ, anh giới thiệu tôi với một người bạn của anh, và anh ấy đã giảng giải cho tôi về sự kỳ diệu của tuổi xuân, còn anh đã hoàn thành bức chân dung về tôi, một bức tranh để lộ cho tôi thấy sự diệu kỳ của sắc đẹp. Trong một khoảnh khắc điên rồ, mà, thậm chí lúc này, tôi cũng không biết mình có ân hận hay không, tôi đã thốt lên một ước ao, có lẽ anh sẽ gọi nó là một lời cầu xin…”
tr: Dorian Gray çiçeği avucunda ezerek, “Yıllar önce, ben genç bir çocukken tanıştık,” dedi. “Sen beni pohpohladın, güzelliğimle gurur duymayı öğrettin bana. Günün birinde bir dostunla tanıştırdın; o bana gençliğin mucizesini açıkladı, senin yapıp bitirdiğin portre de güzelliğin mucizesini serdi gözlerimin önüne. Bir çılgınlık dakikasında... Gerçi şimdi bile buna pişman olup olmadığımı bilemiyorum ya... Bir dilekte bulundum, belki bir yakarı da diyebilirsin buna...
es: —Hace años, cuando no era más que un adolescente —dijo Dorian Gray, aplastando la flor con la mano—, me conociste, me halagaste la vanidad y me enseñaste a sentirme orgulloso de mi belleza. Un día me presentaste a uno de tus amigos, que me explicó la maravilla de la juventud, mientras tú terminabas el retrato que me reveló el milagro de la belleza. En un momento de locura del que, incluso ahora, ignoro aún si lamento o no, formulé un deseo, aunque quizá tú lo llamaras una plegaria...
vi_translation: “Many years ago, when I was just a boy,” Dorian Gray said, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, taught me to be proud of my beauty. One day, you introduced me to a friend of yours, and he explained to me the wonders of youth, while you completed the portrait of me, a painting that revealed to me the marvel of beauty. In a moment of madness, which, even now, I do not know if I regret, I uttered a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer…”
tr_translation: Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, said, "Years ago, when I was a young boy, we met." "You flattered me, taught me to take pride in my beauty. One day, you introduced me to a friend; he explained the miracle of youth to me, and the portrait you had completed revealed the miracle of beauty before my eyes. In a moment of madness... Though even now, I don't know if I regret it... I made a wish, or perhaps you could call it a plea..."
es_translation: —Years ago, when I was nothing more than a teenager —said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower with his hand—, you met me, flattered my vanity, and taught me to take pride in my beauty. One day you introduced me to one of your friends, who explained the wonder of youth to me, while you finished the portrait that revealed to me the miracle of beauty. In a moment of madness, of which even now I still do not know if I regret or not, I made a wish, although perhaps you would call it a prayer...

en: “Can’t you see your ideal in it?” said Dorian bitterly.
vi: “Anh không thấy lý tưởng của anh trong nó à?” Dorian nói, cay đắng.
tr: “İdealini göremiyor musun resimde?” Dorian acı acı sordu.
es: —¿No descubres en él a tu ideal? —preguntó Dorian con amargura.
vi_translation: “Don’t you see your ideal in it?” Dorian said, bitterly.
tr_translation: "Can't you see your ideal in the painting?" Dorian asked bitterly.
es_translation: —Don't you see your ideal in him? —asked Dorian bitterly.

en: At nine o’clock the next morning his servant came in with a cup of chocolate on a tray and opened the shutters. Dorian was sleeping quite peacefully, lying on his right side, with one hand underneath his cheek. He looked like a boy who had been tired out with play, or study.
vi: Lúc 9 giờ sáng, gia nhân của cậu vào với cốc sô-cô-la trên khay, và mở cửa chớp. Dorian đang ngủ rất ngon, nằm nghiêng bên phải, với một tay kê dưới má. Trông cậu như một chú bé mệt lả vì mải chơi hoặc chăm học.
tr: Ertesi sabah saat dokuzda Dorian’ın uşağı tepsi üzerinde bir bardak kakaoyla odaya girdi, panjurları açtı. Dorian sağına yatmış, bir eli yanağının altında, rahat uykulardaydı. Oyun oynamaktan ya da ders çalışmaktan yorulmuş bir çocuğu andırıyordu.
es: Alas nueve de la mañana del día siguiente, el criado entró con una taza de chocolate en una bandeja y abrió las contraventanas. Dorian dormía apaciblemente, tumbado sobre el lado derecho, con una mano bajo la mejilla. Parecía un adolescente agotado por el juego o el estudio.
vi_translation: At 9 o'clock in the morning, his servant came in with a cup of chocolate on a tray and opened the shutters. Dorian was sleeping very soundly, lying on his right side, with one hand under his cheek. He looked like a little boy exhausted from playing too much or studying hard.
tr_translation: The next morning at nine o'clock, Dorian's servant entered the room with a tray holding a glass of cocoa and opened the shutters. Dorian was lying on his right side, one hand under his cheek, sleeping comfortably. He resembled a child tired from playing games or studying.
es_translation: At nine o'clock in the morning the next day, the servant entered with a cup of chocolate on a tray and opened the shutters. Dorian was sleeping peacefully, lying on his right side, with one hand under his cheek. He looked like a teenager exhausted from play or study.

en: This was the man Dorian Gray was waiting for. Every second he kept glancing at the clock. As the minutes went by he became horribly agitated. At last he got up and began to pace up and down the room, looking like a beautiful caged thing. He took long stealthy strides. His hands were curiously cold.
vi: Đó là người mà Dorian Gray đang chờ. Cậu cứ nhìn đồng hồ từng giây. Các phút qua đi, cậu trở nên bối rối khủng khiếp. Cuối cùng cậu đứng dậy, bắt đầu bước tới bước lui trong phòng, trông như một con thú đẹp bị nhốt vào cũi. Cậu sải những bước dài vụng trộm. Tay cậu lạnh một cách kỳ lạ.
tr: İşte Dorian Gray’in beklemekte olduğu adam buydu. Dorian her an duvardaki saate bakıp duruyor, dakikalar geçtikçe içindeki çirkin, kaygılı heyecan artıyordu. En sonunda kalktı, odanın içini arşınlamaya başladı: Kafese kapatılmış güzel bir yaratık gibiydi. Uzun, sinsi adımlarla yürüyordu. Elleri buz kesmişti, nedense.
es: Tal era el hombre que Dorian Gray esperaba. Su mirada se volvía hacia el reloj a cada momento. A medida que pasaban los minutos aumentaba su agitación. Finalmente se levantó y empezó a pasear por la estancia, con el aspecto de un bello animal enjaulado. Caminaba a grandes zancadas que tenían algo de furtivo. Y las manos se le habían quedado extrañamente frías.
vi_translation: That is the person whom Dorian Gray is waiting for. He keeps looking at the clock every second. As the minutes pass, he becomes terribly anxious. Finally, he stands up and begins to pace back and forth in the room, looking like a beautiful beast trapped in a cage. He takes long, stealthy strides. His hands are strangely cold.
tr_translation: This was the man Dorian Gray had been waiting for. Dorian kept looking at the clock on the wall every moment, and as the minutes passed, the ugly, anxious excitement inside him grew. Finally, he got up and began pacing the room: He was like a beautiful creature trapped in a cage. He walked with long, stealthy steps. His hands were ice-cold, for some reason.
es_translation: Such was the man that Dorian Gray was waiting for. His gaze turned towards the clock every moment. As the minutes passed, his agitation increased. Finally, he got up and began to pace around the room, with the appearance of a beautiful caged animal. He walked with long strides that had something furtive about them. And his hands had become strangely cold.

en: “Ask him to come in at once, Francis.” He felt that he was himself again. His mood of cowardice had passed away.
vi: “Mời ông ấy vào ngay đi, Francis.” Cậu thấy mình lại là mình. Tâm trạng hèn nhát của cậu đã biến mất.
tr: “Hemen içeri buyur et, Francis.” Dorian kendine gelmişti artık. Deminki ödlekliği geçip gitmişti.
es: —Hágalo pasar ahora mismo, Francis —sintió que volvía a ser el de siempre. Había superado el momento de cobardía.
vi_translation: "Please let him in immediately, Francis." He felt like himself again. His cowardly mood had vanished.
tr_translation: "Please come in, Francis." Dorian had composed himself by now. The earlier cowardice had passed.
es_translation: —Have him come in right now, Francis —he felt like his old self again. He had overcome the moment of cowardice.

en: “Ah! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian.”
vi: “Chà! Tôi đang chờ anh gọi tôi là Dorian.
tr: “Ah! Bana, Dorian demeni bekliyordum.
es: —¡Ah! Esperaba anhelante a que me llamaras Dorian.
vi_translation: "Wow! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian."
tr_translation: “Ah! I was expecting you to call me, Dorian.”
es_translation: —Ah! I was eagerly waiting for you to call me, Dorian.

en: “Of course I refuse. I will have absolutely nothing to do with it. I don’t care what shame comes on you. You deserve it all. I should not be sorry to see you disgraced, publicly disgraced. How dare you ask me, of all men in the world, to mix myself up in this horror? I should have thought you knew more about people’s characters. Your friend Lord Henry Wotton can’t have taught you much about psychology, whatever else he has taught you. Nothing will induce me to stir a step to help you. You have come to the wrong man. Go to some of your friends. Don’t come to me.”
vi: “Dĩ nhiên tôi từ chối. Tôi sẽ tuyệt đối không liên quan gì với nó. Tôi chẳng quan tâm nỗi nhục nào sẽ đến với anh. Anh hoàn toàn xứng đáng với nó. Tôi sẽ không lấy làm buồn khi được thấy anh bị ruồng bỏ, bị ruồng bỏ công khai. Sao anh dám yêu cầu tôi, giữa bao nhiêu người trên đời, dính líu vào vụ ghê rợn này? Tôi cứ tưởng anh hiểu biết nhiều hơn về tính cách con người. Huân tước Henry Wotton, bạn anh, không thể dạy anh nhiều về tâm lý học, dù ông ấy đã dạy anh nhiều điều khác. Chẳng có gì xui khiến được tôi nhích một bước để giúp anh. Anh đã đến nhầm người. Hãy đến ai đó khác trong số các bạn anh. Đừng đến gặp tôi.”
tr: “Tabii ki reddediyorum. Hiçbir şekilde karışmayacağım bu olaya. Bu yüzden rezil olsan da vız gelir. Her türlü rezilliği hak ettin sen. Senin, hem de elâlem içinde beş paralık olduğunu görsem de üzülmem. Dünyada başka adam kalmamış gibi bir de benden, böyle feci bir işe bulaşmamı hangi yüzle isteyebiliyorsun? İnsan karakterini daha iyi anladığını sanırdım. Dostun Lord Henry Wotton sana başka neler öğretti bilemem ya, ruhbilim dalında pek bir şey öğretmemiş olsa gerek. Dünyada hiçbir baskı benim sana yardım etmemi sağlayamaz. Yanlış adam seçtin. Dostlarından birine git. Bana gelme.
es: —Claro que me niego. No quiero tener nada que ver con ello. No me importa lo que te acarree. Mereces todo lo que te suceda. No me entristecerá verte deshonrado, públicamente deshonrado. ¿Cómo te atreves a pedirme, a mí especialmente, que tome parte en ese horror? Hubiera creído que entendías mejor la manera de ser de las personas. Quizá tu amigo lord Henry Wotton no te ha enseñado tanto sobre psicología, aunque te haya enseñado mucho sobre otras cosas. Nada me llevará a dar un paso por ayudarte. Te has equivocado de persona. Acude a alguno de tus amigos. No a mí.
vi_translation: “Of course I refuse. I will absolutely have nothing to do with it. I don't care what disgrace will come to you. You completely deserve it. I will not be saddened to see you being abandoned, being publicly abandoned. How dare you ask me, among so many people in the world, to get involved in this horrendous affair? I thought you understood more about human nature. Lord Henry Wotton, your friend, cannot teach you much about psychology, even though he has taught you many other things. Nothing could compel me to take a step to help you. You have come to the wrong person. Go to someone else among your friends. Do not come to see me.
tr_translation: “Of course I refuse. I will not get involved in this matter in any way. So, even if you become disgraced, it doesn't matter to me. You deserve every kind of disgrace. Even if I see you being humiliated in front of everyone, I wouldn't feel sorry. As if there were no other men left in the world, how can you ask me to get involved in such a terrible thing with what face? I thought you understood human character better. I don't know what else your friend Lord Henry Wotton has taught you, but he must not have taught you much in the field of psychology. No pressure in the world can make me help you. You chose the wrong man. Go to one of your friends. Don't come to me.”
es_translation: —Of course, I refuse. I don't want to have anything to do with it. I don't care what it brings you. You deserve everything that happens to you. It won't sadden me to see you dishonored, publicly dishonored. How dare you ask me, especially me, to take part in that horror? I would have thought you understood people's nature better. Maybe your friend Lord Henry Wotton hasn't taught you much about psychology, even though he has taught you a lot about other things. Nothing will make me take a step to help you. You have chosen the wrong person. Go to one of your friends. Not to me.

en: “Murder! Good God, Dorian, is that what you have come to? I shall not inform upon you. It is not my business. Besides, without my stirring in the matter, you are certain to be arrested. Nobody ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I will have nothing to do with it.”
vi: “Tội sát nhân! Chúa lòng lành, Dorian, anh đã đến mức này sao? Tôi sẽ không khai ra anh. Đó không phải việc của tôi. Vả lại, dẫu tôi có không nhúc nhích gì trong vụ này, anh chắc chắn vẫn sẽ bị bắt. Chưa ai từng phạm tội mà rồi lại không làm gì đó ngu ngốc. Nhưng tôi sẽ không dính vào nó.”
tr: “Cinayet mi, aman Tanrım! Sonunda işi buna mı vardırdın, Dorian? Seni ele verecek değilim. Beni ilgilendirmez. Zaten ben işi kurcalamasam da sen er geç ele geçersin. Suç işleyenler mutlaka bir aptallık yaparlar. Ama bu işe ben bulaşmayacağım.
es: —¡Asesinato! ¡Cielo santo, Dorian! ¿A eso has llegado finalmente? No te denunciaré. No es asunto mío. Además, sin necesidad de que yo mueva un dedo acabarán por detenerte. Nadie comete nunca un delito sin hacer algo estúpido. Pero me niego a intervenir.
vi_translation: “Murder! Good Lord, Dorian, have you gone this far? I will not turn you in. That is not my business. Besides, even if I do nothing in this matter, you will surely be caught. No one has ever committed a crime without doing something foolish afterward. But I will not get involved in it.”
tr_translation: “Murder, oh my God! Did you finally come to this, Dorian? I won't turn you in. It doesn't concern me. Even if I don't investigate, you'll get caught sooner or later. Criminals always make a mistake. But I won't get involved in this.”
es_translation: —Murder! Good heavens, Dorian! Is that what you've come to at last? I won't turn you in. It's none of my business. Besides, without me lifting a finger, they'll end up catching you. No one ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I refuse to get involved.

en: After two or three minutes of terrible silence, Dorian turned round and came and stood behind him, putting his hand upon his shoulder.
vi: Sau đôi ba phút im lặng đáng sợ, Dorian quay lại, đến đứng sau lưng y, đặt tay lên vai y.
tr: Korkunç bir sessizlikle dolu birkaç dakikanın sonunda Dorian döndü, geldi konuğunun yanında durdu, elini onun omzuna koydu.
es: Al cabo de dos o tres minutos de terrible silencio, Dorian, abandonando la ventana, se situó tras él y le puso una mano en el hombro.
vi_translation: After a few terrifying minutes of silence, Dorian turned around, stood behind him, and placed his hand on his shoulder.
tr_translation: After a few minutes filled with a dreadful silence, Dorian turned, came to stand beside his guest, and placed his hand on his shoulder.
es_translation: After two or three minutes of terrible silence, Dorian, leaving the window, positioned himself behind him and placed a hand on his shoulder.

en: As the hall door shut, Campbell started nervously, and having got up from the chair, went over to the chimney-piece. He was shivering with a kind of ague. For nearly twenty minutes, neither of the men spoke. A fly buzzed noisily about the room, and the ticking of the clock was like the beat of a hammer.
vi: Lúc cửa ngoài sảnh đóng lại, Campbell giật bắn mình lo lắng, và, đứng lên khỏi ghế, đi đến gần mặt lò sưởi. Y run như thể bị sốt rét. Suốt gần hai chục phút, không ai nói gì. Một con ruồi bay vo ve ồn ào quanh phòng, tiếng tích tắc của đồng hồ như tiếng gõ búa.
tr: Kapı kapandığı sırada Campbell ürkerek şöyle bir irkildi, sonra yerinden kalkarak şömine başına gitti. Sıtması varmış gibi titriyordu. Yirmi dakika kadar ikisi de konuşmadılar. Odanın içinde, vızıldayarak dolaşan bir sinek vardı. Saatin tıklaması çekiç vuruşu gibiydi.
es: Al cerrarse la puerta principal, Campbell tuvo un sobresalto y, levantándose de la silla, se acercó a la chimenea. Temblaba como atacado por la fiebre. Durante cerca de veinte minutos nadie habló. Una mosca zumbó ruidosamente por el cuarto y el tictac del reloj era como el golpear de un martillo.
vi_translation: When the outer hall door closed, Campbell started in worry, and, standing up from his chair, went near the fireplace. He shivered as if he had malaria. For nearly twenty minutes, no one said anything. A fly buzzed noisily around the room, the ticking of the clock sounded like hammer blows.
tr_translation: As the door closed, Campbell flinched in fright, then got up and went to the fireplace. He was trembling as if he had malaria. For about twenty minutes, neither of them spoke. There was a fly buzzing around the room. The ticking of the clock was like the strike of a hammer.
es_translation: When the front door closed, Campbell was startled and, getting up from the chair, he approached the fireplace. He was trembling as if struck by a fever. For about twenty minutes, no one spoke. A fly buzzed loudly around the room and the ticking of the clock was like the pounding of a hammer.

en: “Shall I leave the things here, sir?” he asked Campbell.
vi: “Tôi có thể để đồ lại đây không, thưa ngài?” hắn hỏi Campbell.
tr: Uşak, “Bunları buraya mı bırakayım, efendim?” diye Campbell’e sordu.
es: —¿He de dejar aquí estas cosas? —le preguntó a Campbell.
vi_translation: "May I leave my things here, sir?" he asked Campbell.
tr_translation: "Shall I leave these here, sir?" the servant asked Campbell.
es_translation: —Should I leave these things here? —he asked Campbell.

en: Campbell frowned and bit his lip. “It will take about five hours,” he answered.
vi: Campbell cau mày, cắn môi. “Nó sẽ mất độ năm tiếng,” y trả lời.
tr: Campbell kaşlarını çatarak dudağını dişledi. “Aşağı yukarı beş saat.
es: Campbell frunció el entrecejo y se mordió los labios. —Unas cinco horas —respondió.
vi_translation: Campbell frowned, biting his lip. “It will take about five hours,” he replied.
tr_translation: Campbell frowned and bit his lip. "About five hours."
es_translation: Campbell frowned and bit his lips. —About five hours —he replied.

en: “It is nothing to me. I don’t require you,” said Campbell coldly.
vi: “Chuyện vặt với tôi. Tôi không cần đến anh,” Campbell nói, lạnh nhạt.
tr: “Alan, içeri giremeyeceğim galiba. Campbell soğuk soğuk, “Bence hava hoş,” dedi. “Sana ihtiyacım yok.
es: —No importa. No te necesito para nada —respondió Campbell con frialdad.
vi_translation: "A trivial matter to me. I don't need you," Campbell said coldly.
tr_translation: "Alan, I don't think I can go inside." Campbell said coolly, "I think the weather is nice." "I don't need you."
es_translation: —It doesn't matter. I don't need you for anything —replied Campbell coldly.

en: Dorian half opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of his portrait leering in the sunlight. On the floor in front of it the torn curtain was lying. He remembered that the night before he had forgotten, for the first time in his life, to hide the fatal canvas, and was about to rush forward, when he drew back with a shudder.
vi: Dorian mở hé cửa. Khi làm vậy, cậu thấy mặt bức chân dung cậu liếc đểu cậu trong nắng. Trên sàn, đối diện nó, tấm màn rách đang nằm. Cậu nhớ ra là, đêm trước, lần đầu trong đời, cậu quên che tấm toan tai hại ấy, và đã gần như lao về phía trước, khi bị kéo giật lại bởi một cơn rùng mình.
tr: Dorian kapıyı araladı. Bu sırada portresinin gün ışığında pis pis sırıtan suratını gördü. Dibinde, yerde yırtılmış perde duruyordu. Dorian ilk kez dün gece uğursuz resmi örtmediğini anımsadı. Tam ileri atılacakken bir ürpertiyle sarsılarak geri çekildi.
es: Dorian Gray abrió a medias la puerta. Al hacerlo, vio el rostro del retrato, mirándolo, socarrón, iluminado por la luz del sol. En el suelo, delante, se hallaba la cortina rasgada. Recordó que la noche anterior había olvidado, por primera vez en su vida, esconder el lienzo maldito, y se disponía a abalanzarse, cuando retrocedió, estremecido.
vi_translation: Dorian slightly opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of his portrait sneering at him in the sunlight. On the floor, opposite it, the torn curtain was lying. He remembered that, the night before, for the first time in his life, he had forgotten to cover the cursed canvas, and had almost rushed forward, when he was pulled back by a shudder.
tr_translation: Dorian slightly opened the door. At that moment, he saw the sneering face of his portrait in the daylight. At the bottom, the torn curtain lay on the floor. Dorian remembered for the first time that he hadn't covered the ominous painting last night. Just as he was about to move forward, he recoiled with a shudder.
es_translation: Dorian Gray half-opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of the portrait, mocking, illuminated by the sunlight. On the floor in front of it lay the torn curtain. He remembered that the night before he had forgotten, for the first time in his life, to hide the cursed canvas, and he was about to pounce when he recoiled, trembling.

en: It was long after seven when Campbell came back into the library. He was pale, but absolutely calm. “I have done what you asked me to do,” he muttered. “And now, good-bye. Let us never see each other again.”
vi: Lúc Campbell quay lại thư viện thì đã hơn bảy giờ khá lâu. Y tái nhợt, nhưng hoàn toàn điềm tĩnh. “Tôi đã làm xong những gì anh yêu cầu tôi làm,” y lẩm bẩm. “Và giờ thì tạm biệt. Chúng ta sẽ không bao giờ gặp nhau nữa.”
tr: Campbell yeniden kitaplığa geldiğinde saat yediyi çoktan geçmişti. Genç adam solgun ama son derece serinkanlıydı. “Benden istediğini yaptım,” dedi. “Şimdi artık elveda. Bir daha hiç görüşmeyelim.
es: Hacía tiempo que habían dado las siete cuando Campbell se presentó de nuevo en la biblioteca. Estaba pálido, pero muy tranquilo. —He hecho lo que me habías pedido que hiciera —murmuró—. Y ahora, adiós. Espero que no volvamos a vernos nunca.
vi_translation: When Campbell returned to the library, it was well past seven o'clock. He was pale, but completely calm. “I have done what you asked me to do,” he muttered. “And now, goodbye. We will never see each other again.”
tr_translation: When Campbell returned to the library, it was already past seven o'clock. The young man was pale but extremely calm. "I did what you asked of me," he said. "Now it's goodbye. Let's never see each other again."
es_translation: It had been a while since seven o'clock had struck when Campbell appeared again in the library. He was pale, but very calm. —I have done what you asked me to do —he murmured—. And now, goodbye. I hope we never see each other again.

en: As soon as Campbell had left, he went upstairs. There was a horrible smell of nitric acid in the room. But the thing that had been sitting at the table was gone.
vi: Ngay khi Campbell vừa về, cậu lên gác luôn. Trong phòng có mùi khủng khiếp của a-xít nit-ric. Nhưng cái thứ từng ngồi bên bàn đã biến mất.
tr: Campbell gider gitmez Dorian yukarı çıktı. Odada iğrenç bir kezzap kokusu vardı. Ama daha önce masa başında oturmakta olan o şeyin yerinde yeller esiyordu.
es: Tan pronto como Campbell salió de la casa, subió al ático. En la habitación había un horrible olor a ácido nítrico. Pero la cosa sentada ante la mesa había desaparecido.
vi_translation: As soon as Campbell got back, he went straight upstairs. There was a terrible smell of nitric acid in the room. But the thing that had been sitting at the table was gone.
tr_translation: As soon as Campbell left, Dorian went upstairs. There was a disgusting smell of acid in the room. But the thing that had been sitting at the desk earlier was nowhere to be seen.
es_translation: As soon as Campbell left the house, he went up to the attic. In the room, there was a horrible smell of nitric acid. But the thing sitting at the table had disappeared.

en: “She does not remember my short frocks at all, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well at Vienna thirty years ago, and how décolletée she was then.”
vi: “Cô ấy không nhớ được tí nào về những chiếc váy ngắn của tôi đâu, huân tước Henry. Nhưng tôi nhớ cô ấy rất rõ ở Vienna ba mươi năm trước, và hồi ấy cô ấy décolletée1 thế nào.” 1 Mặc áo hở vai.
tr: “O benim kısa elbiselerimi hiç de anımsatmıyor, Lord Henry. Ama ben onu otuz yıl öncesinin Viyana’sından pek iyi anımsıyorum: O zaman nasıl décolletée gezdiğini falan.
es: —No se acuerda en absoluto de mis trajes cortos, lord Henry. Pero yo la recuerdo perfectamente en Viena hace treinta años, así como los escotes que llevaba por entonces.
vi_translation: “She doesn't remember anything about my short dresses, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well in Vienna thirty years ago, and how décolletée1 she was back then.” 1 Wear an off-shoulder top.
tr_translation: “It doesn't remind me of my short dresses at all, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well from Vienna thirty years ago: how she used to walk around décolletée and all.”
es_translation: —You don't remember my short dresses at all, Lord Henry. But I remember you perfectly in Vienna thirty years ago, as well as the necklines you wore back then.

en: “The husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal classes,” said Lord Henry, sipping his wine.
vi: “Mấy thằng chồng của gái đẹp toàn là bọn trộm cắp,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa nhắp rượu.
tr: Lord Henry, “Çok güzel kadınların kocaları ağır suç işleyenlerin sınıfından sayılır,” diyerek şarabından bir yudum aldı.
es: —Los maridos de mujeres muy hermosas pertenecen a la clase delictiva —dijo lord Henry, saboreando el vino.
vi_translation: "The husbands of beautiful women are all thieves," said Lord Henry as he sipped his drink.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "Husbands of very beautiful women are considered to be in the class of heavy criminals," he said, taking a sip of his wine.
es_translation: —Husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal class —said Lord Henry, savoring the wine.

en: “But what world says that?” asked Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows. “It can only be the next world. This world and I are on excellent terms.”
vi: “Nhưng người nào nói vậy?” huân tước Henry nói, nhướng mày. “Chỉ có thể là người đời sau. Người đời này thì tôi có quan hệ rất tốt.”
tr: Lord Henry, “İyi ama hangi dünyaymış o?” diye kaşlarını kaldırdı. “Olsa olsa öteki dünyadır. Çünkü bu dünyayla benim aramdan su sızmıyor.
es: —Pero, ¿qué mundo dice eso? —preguntó lord Henry, alzando las cejas—. Sólo puede ser el mundo venidero. Este mundo y yo mantenemos excelentes relaciones.
vi_translation: “But who said that?” Lord Henry said, raising an eyebrow. “It could only be someone from the future. I have a very good relationship with people of this time.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows, "Well, which world is that?" "It must be the other world. Because there is no gap between this world and me."
es_translation: —But, which world says that? —asked Lord Henry, raising his eyebrows—. It can only be the world to come. This world and I maintain excellent relations.

en: Lord Henry looked serious for some moments. “It is perfectly monstrous,” he said, at last, “the way people go about nowadays saying things against one behind one’s back that are absolutely and entirely true.”
vi: Huân tước Henry trông có vẻ rất nghiêm túc được một lúc. “Gớm guốc thay,” rốt cuộc y nói, “cái cách mọi người ngày nay cứ xì xào đồn đại sau lưng ta những chuyện hoàn toàn tuyệt đối chính xác.”
tr: Lord Henry bir süre ciddi durdu. Sonunda, “Düpedüz rezalet yani!” dedi. “Bugünlerde herkes kişinin ardından öyle laflar çıkartıyor ki hepsi de kesinlikle, yüzde yüz doğru.
es: Lord Henry adoptó por unos instantes un aire serio. —Es perfectamente intolerable —dijo, finalmente— la manera en que la gente va por ahí diciendo, a espaldas de uno, cosas que son absoluta y completamente ciertas.
vi_translation: Lord Henry looked very serious for a moment. “How dreadful,” he finally said, “the way people nowadays gossip behind one's back about things that are absolutely and entirely true.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry stood serious for a while. Finally, he said, "It's an outright scandal!" "These days, everyone spreads such rumors about a person that they are absolutely, one hundred percent true."
es_translation: Lord Henry adopted a serious air for a moment. "It is perfectly intolerable," he said finally, "the way people go around saying, behind one's back, things that are absolutely and completely true."

en: “I hope so,” said his hostess, laughing. “But really, if you all worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous way, I shall have to marry again so as to be in the fashion.”
vi: “Tôi hy vọng thế,” bà chủ tiệc vừa cười vừa nói. “Nhưng thực sự là nếu tất cả các anh tôn sùng ma-đam de Ferrol theo cái kiểu lố bịch này thì tôi sẽ phải tái hôn để theo được mốt.”
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Öyledir umarım,” diye güldü. “Ama sahi söylüyorum, eğer hepiniz Madam Ferrol’a böyle ayılıp bayılıyorsanız benim de moda olabilmek için yeniden evlenmem gerekecek, demektir.
es: —Eso espero —dijo, riendo, la anfitriona—. Pero si todos ustedes adoran a madame de Ferroll de esa manera tan ridícula, tendré que volver a casarme para estar a la moda.
vi_translation: "I hope so," the hostess said with a smile. "But really, if all of you worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous manner, I will have to remarry to keep up with the trend."
tr_translation: The hostess laughed, "I hope so." "But I'm serious, if you all are so enamored with Madam Ferrol, it means I'll have to get married again to be in fashion.""
es_translation: —I hope so —said the hostess, laughing—. But if all of you adore Madame de Ferroll in such a ridiculous manner, I will have to remarry to stay in fashion.

en: “Narborough wasn’t perfect,” cried the old lady.
vi: “Narborough cũng không hoàn hảo đâu,” bà già kêu lên.
tr: Yaşlı hanım, “Kocam Narborough kusursuz değildi ki!” dedi.
es: —Narborough no era perfecto —exclamó la anciana señora.
vi_translation: “Narborough is not perfect either,” the old lady exclaimed.
tr_translation: The elderly lady said, "My husband Narborough was not perfect!"
es_translation: —Narborough was not perfect —exclaimed the elderly lady.

en: “Of course it is true, Lord Henry. If we women did not love you for your defects, where would you all be? Not one of you would ever be married. You would be a set of unfortunate bachelors. Not, however, that that would alter you much. Nowadays all the married men live like bachelors, and all the bachelors like married men.”
vi: “Dĩ nhiên là chính xác rồi, huân tước Henry. Nếu đàn bà chúng tôi không yêu các anh vì nhược điểm của các anh, thì tất cả các anh rồi sẽ ra làm sao? Không một ai trong số các anh sẽ có lúc lấy vợ. Các anh sẽ là một lũ độc thân bất hạnh. Không, dẫu sao thì điều ấy cũng chẳng thay đổi được các anh là mấy. Ngày nay ông nào có vợ cũng sống như người độc thân, còn ông nào độc thân thì cũng cứ như người có vợ.”
tr: “Elbette öyle, Lord Henry. Biz kadınlar sizleri kusurlarınızdan ötürü sevmeseydik haliniz nice olurdu? Bir tekiniz bile evlenemezdiniz. Bir bahtsız bekârlar sürüsü! Öte yandan bekâr kalmak da sizleri pek öyle değiştirmezdi ya! Günümüzde bütün evli erkekler bekâr hayatı sürüyor, bütün bekârlar da evliymiş gibi yaşıyor.
es: —Claro que es cierto, lord Henry. Si las mujeres no amaran a los hombres por sus defectos, ¿dónde estarían todos ustedes? Ninguno se habría casado. Serían una colección de solteros infelices. Aunque tampoco eso los habría cambiado mucho. En los días que corren todos los hombres casados viven como solteros, y todos los solteros como casados.
vi_translation: "Of course it's accurate, Lord Henry. If we women didn't love you for your weaknesses, what would become of all of you? None of you would ever get married. You would all be an unhappy bunch of bachelors. No, after all, that wouldn't change you much. Nowadays, a married man lives like a bachelor, and a bachelor lives like a married man."
tr_translation: “Of course, Lord Henry. If we women didn't love you for your flaws, what would become of you? Not a single one of you would be able to marry. A hapless herd of bachelors! On the other hand, remaining single wouldn't change you much either! Nowadays, all married men live like bachelors, and all bachelors live as if they were married.”
es_translation: —Of course it's true, Lord Henry. If women didn't love men for their flaws, where would all of you be? None would have gotten married. You would be a collection of unhappy bachelors. Although that wouldn't have changed you much either. Nowadays, all married men live like bachelors, and all bachelors like married men.

en: “Fin de siêcle,” murmured Lord Henry.
vi: "Fin de siècle1," huân tước Henry lẩm bẩm.
tr: Lord Henry, “Fin de siécle, yüzyılın sonu,” diye mırıldandı.
es: —Fin de siécle —murmuró lord Henry.
vi_translation: "End of the century," Lord Henry muttered.
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "Fin de siècle, the end of the century."
es_translation: —End of the century —murmured Lord Henry.

en: “What nonsense people talk about happy marriages!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her.”
vi: “Mọi người đã nói biết bao nhiêu thứ nhảm nhí về các cuộc hôn nhân hạnh phúc!” huân tước Henry kêu lên. “Đàn ông có thể hạnh phúc với bất cứ cô nào, miễn đừng yêu cô ấy.”
tr: Lord Henry, “İnsanlar mutlu evlilik konusunda nasıl da saçmalarlar!” dedi. “Bir erkek herhangi bir kadınla mutlu olabilir, yeter ki onu sevmesin.
es: —¡Qué cosas tan absurdas dice la gente sobre los matrimonios felices! —exclamó lord Henry—. Un hombre puede ser feliz con una mujer siempre que no la quiera.
vi_translation: “People have said so many nonsensical things about happy marriages!” Lord Henry exclaimed. “A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "How people do talk nonsense about happy marriages!" "A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her."
es_translation: —What absurd things people say about happy marriages! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. A man can be happy with a woman as long as he does not love her.

en: “I fear so,” she said, laughing, as she stood up. “A thousand pardons, my dear Lady Ruxton,” she added, “I didn’t see you hadn’t finished your cigarette.”
vi: “Tôi e là vậy,” bà vừa nói vừa cười, lúc bà đứng dậy. “Ngàn lần xin lỗi, bà Ruxton yêu quý của tôi,” bà nói thêm. “Tôi không thấy bà chưa hút xong thuốc.
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Korkarım öyle olur,” diye gülerek ayağa kalktı. Sonra, “Bin kez özür dilerim, azizim Leydi Ruxton,” diye ekledi. “Sigaranızı bitirmediğinizi görmemiştim.
es: —Mucho me temo —dijo ella riendo, mientras se ponía en pie—. Mil perdones, mi querida lady Ruxton -añadió al instante—. Veo que no ha terminado usted su cigarrillo.
vi_translation: “I'm afraid so,” she said with a smile, as she stood up. “A thousand apologies, my dear Mrs. Ruxton,” she added. “I didn't realize you hadn't finished your cigarette.”
tr_translation: The hostess stood up laughing, "I'm afraid it will be so," she said. Then she added, "A thousand apologies, my dear Lady Ruxton." "I hadn't noticed you hadn't finished your cigarette."
es_translation: —I greatly fear —she said laughing, as she stood up—. A thousand pardons, my dear Lady Ruxton —she added instantly—. I see that you have not finished your cigarette.

en: “Now, mind you don’t stay too long over your politics and scandal,” cried Lady Narborough from the door. “If you do, we are sure to squabble upstairs.”
vi: “Giờ thì hãy lưu ý là anh đừng nấn ná quá lâu với các quan điểm chính trị và những vụ tai tiếng nhé,” bà Narborough la lên từ cửa. “Nếu anh làm thế, chúng tôi chắc chắn sẽ cãi nhau trên gác.”
tr: Leydi Narborough eşikte dönerek, “Sakın politika konularınızla dedikodularınızı fazla uzatmayın,” diye seslendi. “Yoksa bizler yukarıda hırlaşmaya başlarız.
es: —Por favor, caballeros, no se queden ustedes demasiado tiempo hablando de política y de escándalos —exclamó lady Narborough desde la puerta—. Si lo hacen, acabaremos peleándonos en el piso de arriba.
vi_translation: "Now, be sure not to linger too long on politics and scandals," Mrs. Narborough called out from the door. "If you do, we are sure to argue upstairs."
tr_translation: Lady Narborough turned at the threshold and called out, "Don't drag out your politics and gossip too much." "Otherwise, we will start bickering upstairs."
es_translation: —Please, gentlemen, do not spend too much time talking about politics and scandals —exclaimed Lady Narborough from the door—. If you do, we will end up fighting upstairs.

en: “I am quite well, Harry. I am tired. That is all.”
vi: “Tôi ổn mà, Harry. Tôi hơi mệt. Chỉ vậy thôi.”
tr: “İyiyim, Harry. Biraz yorgunum, o kadar.
es: —Estoy perfectamente, Harry. Un poco cansado. Eso es todo.
vi_translation: “I'm fine, Harry. I'm just a bit tired. That's all.”
tr_translation: “I'm fine, Harry. Just a bit tired, that's all.”
es_translation: —I'm perfectly fine, Harry. A little tired. That's all.

en: “Oh, yes, Harry.”
vi: “À, vâng, Harry.”
tr: “Elbette, Harry.
es: —Sí, Harry.
vi_translation: “Ah, yes, Harry.”
tr_translation: "Of course, Harry.""
es_translation: —Yes, Harry.

en: “How long has she been married?” asked Dorian.
vi: “Cô ấy lấy chồng bao lâu rồi?” Dorian hỏi.
tr: Dorian, “Ne kadar süredir evli?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Cuánto tiempo lleva casada? —preguntó Dorian.
vi_translation: “How long has she been married?” Dorian asked.
tr_translation: Dorian asked, "How long have you been married?"
es_translation: —How long have you been married? —asked Dorian.
